II.2.4. Determinação de elementos maiores, menores e traço em zircão por LA-

Q-ICPMS. 

 

 

A implantação da metodologia para a determinação de elementos menores e 

traço em zircão foi baseada nos trabalhos de Gao et al. (2002) e Yuan et al. (2008). 

Foi importante também a experiência desenvolvida no Laboratório de Química e 

ICP-MS (Andrade et al, 2010, 2014) na implantação de metodologia para análise de 

elementos traço em zircão em outros materiais de referência geológicos, tais como 

BHVO-2G, BCR-2G, BIR-1G, provenientes do USGS (2002) e nos vidros de rochas 

komatíiticas GOR-128 e GOR-132G, de basaltos KL-2G e ML-3BG e do quartzo 

diorito T-1G, preparados pelo Max-Planck-Institut für Chemie da Alemanha (Jochum 

et al., 2005).  

As análises foram efetuadas utilizando-se o equipamento de Laser Ablation 

modelo UP-213AF da New Wave/ESI com a célula de amostra modelo “supercell” e 

o espectrômetro de massa com analisador quadrupolo modelo Elan-6100DRC da 

PerkinElmer. 

Devido à dificuldade em se obter materiais sintéticos de referência bem 

caracterizados do tipo zircão, optou-se por efetuar o teste da metodologia 

implantada por análise de materiais de referência naturais. Os materiais escolhidos e 

disponíveis foram os seguintes minerais de zircão: GJ-1 e 91500, já caracterizados e 

bem descritos na literatura, nas análises de razões isotópicas U-Th-Pb para datação, 

a maioria apresentando dados para os teores de elementos traço. 

  O zircão GJ-1, proveniente de um comerciante de gemas de Sidney, foi 

descrito inicialmente por Jackson et al (2004), e alguns dados para os teores dos 

elementos traço foram obtidos para os cristais com coloração vermelha por Yuan et 

al. (2008). O material de referência zircão 91500 é um único cristal com massa de 

238 gramas, proveniente de Kuhel Lake (Ontário, Canadá), descrito e monitorado 

para teste de homogeneidade para idade U-Pb por “secondary ion mass 



 

56  Tese de Doutoramento S. Andrade 

spectrometry” (SIMS) por Wiedenbeck et al (1995). A abundância de REE para esse 

zircão 91500 foi obtida por SHRIMP por Sano et al (2002), pelas técnicas de SIMS, e 

INAA por Wiedenbeck et al (1995, 2004) e, também, por LA-ICPMS, por Yuan et al 

(2004). O material utilizado nas análises deste trabalho foi obtido em 2013 pelo IGc-

USP, tratando-se de pedaços do cristal inicial provenientes do segundo lote desse 

material de referência preparado e analisado por Michael Wiedenbeck em conjunto 

com o Harvard Mineralogical Museum em 2012 e que tem sido comercializado pelo 

International Association of Geoanalists (IAGeo, 2015).  

Para a calibração, controle de drift instrumental (variação das intensidades 

com o tempo numa mesma amostra) e do fracionamento, utilizou-se o material de 

referência na forma de vidro sintético SRM-610 do National Institute of Standards 

(NIST) com valores de referência fornecidos pelo próprio NIST e também no site do 

Georem (2005).  

 

 

II.2.4.1. Metodologia analítica utilizada 

 

 

Na metodologia de determinação de elementos traço em zircão pela técnica 

de LA-ICPMS, no tempo médio de 120 segundos, são analisados 34 elementos, 

cujos isótopos e dados de aquisição do sinal são fornecidos na Tabela II.1. Nos 

primeiros 60 segundos de análise são efetuados medidas de branco, que são 

leituras de todos os isótopos nas condições normais de análises, mas sem o 

acionamento do laser. Essas determinações são efetuadas na mistura do gás hélio, 

que passa pela cela de amostra do sistema de laser ablation, e do argônio, que 

provém do nebulizador do ICP-MS que se junta ao hélio por uma conexão em T para 

atingir o plasma. Esses dados de linha de base (background) são utilizados no 

cálculo do branco e dos limites de detecção e quantificação para cada elemento em 

cada uma das amostras. A análise de branco é apropriada porque leva em 

consideração qualquer contribuição além dos gases e do sistema que possa vir da 

célula onde são colocadas as amostras (e.g., contaminação das paredes dos tubos 

de transporte das partículas de amostras; efeito memória no sistema). Os 60 



 

S. Andrade Tese de Doutoramento 57 

segundos seguintes são usados para aquisição de dados analíticos do material 

retirado pelo laser por ablação da amostra.  

Os parâmetros instrumentais para o espectrômetro Elan-6100DRC da 

PerkinElmer, assim como para o sistema de Laser Ablation da New Wave UP-

213/AF são também apresentados na Tabela II.1; os de aquisição de dados são 

fornecidos na Tabela II.2. Os dados são adquiridos no modo de busca do pico (peak 

hopping) com tempo de ajuste entre cada isótopo (settling time) de 2 ms, MCA igual 

a um, detector no modo dual (analógico e pulso) e modo padrão (ou standard, sem 

uso de células de reação ou colisão); o protocolo de aquisição de dados é do tipo 

tempo por intensidade (time-resolved) do software próprio do espectrômetro de 

massa. Esse protocolo de aquisição permite a aquisição de sinal como função do 

tempo e os resultados são reportados como intensidade do sinal (cps) versus tempo 

(s), permitindo reconhecimento de qualquer heterogeneidade na superfície analisada 

(modo de ablação do tipo trincheira: raster) ou do volume ablado (modo furo: spot). 

Para as análises dos elementos traço, devido ao crescimento concêntrico 

oscilatório observado principalmente em zircão magmático, ou mesmo os setoriais 

em alguns tipos de zircão metamórfico ou simplesmente alterados por influência de 

fluidos, foram utilizados, principalmente, o modo raster de 80 µm com spot de 40 ou 

30 µm e o passo do raster de 1-2 µm/s. O uso desse modo raster permite visualizar 

durante toda a análise a superfície do mineral que está sendo ablada, sem perda 

expressiva de sinal pelo aprofundamento do furo, ou aumento do fracionamento dos 

elementos retirados, já que o modo raster propicia abrir uma trincheira rasa (~ 10-

20µm) que permite facilmente a saída do material ablado. A baixa velocidade de 

passo do laser também permite a formação de partículas menores durante todo o 

tempo de análise, o que influi bastante minimizando o fracionamento observado 

(detalhes em Kosler, 2008). 

Os resultados obtidos são tratados em tempo real pelo software Glitter ® (Van 

Achterbergh et al, 2001), que efetua on-line as correções do drift instrumental 

através do uso de padrão interno de um elemento previamente escolhido e de 

material de referência externo, além do cálculo dos teores dos elementos em 

análise. As equações matemáticas usadas para cálculos das concentrações dos 

elementos analisados, bem como os dados estatísticos (como limites de detecção, 

desvio padrão, etc.) são fornecidos em Jackson et al (2001) e Andrade et al (2014).

Para a metodologia do zircão utilizou-se o material de referência NIST-610 

como referência externa e testou-se o uso dos teores estequiométricos de SiO2 

(igual a 33%,  proporção em peso) e ZrO2 (como 67%) como valores do padrão 

interno calibrador no mineral zircão. Em geral, para outros minerais não 

estequiométricos os teores devem ser determinados por microssonda eletrônica; 

para o zircão, e outros minerais de composição estequiométrica, essa aproximação 

é amplamente utilizada na literatura (Liu et al, 2010). Os resultados obtidos com o 

uso de ambos os elementos calibradores são discutidos a seguir. O tratamento de 

dados on-line com esse software também permite a verificação dos teores de

background, sinal espectral (se existe inclusões ou mudanças abruptas nos teores 

dos elementos), qualidade analítica (DL, 1 sigma, etc.) e  recálculos dos resultados 

em concentrações, normalizados pelo condrito, e gráficos associados.

Entre cada amostra é efetuada uma lavagem da cela de amostra por 

aproximadamente 60 s com o gás hélio, um procedimento que permite, além da 

limpeza da cela para a próxima amostra, uma estabilização do background mais 

rápida que utilizar o argônio. As leituras dos materiais de referência NIST-610 (a, b, 

c, d, e, f) são utilizadas como padrão interno e também para correção de drift ao 

longo do tempo de todo o procedimento analítico. Entre o aquecimento do sistema, 

com estabilização do laser e do plasma, e otimização das condições diárias de 

análise, o tempo total de análises é de quase 3 horas para 24 amostras.

limites de detecção dos elementos analisados nessa metodologia.

II.2.4.2. Resultados obtidos para materiais de referência 

 

 

Os dados apresentados a seguir foram obtidos para os materiais de 

referência zircão 91500 e zircão GJ-1 no espectrômetro ICP-MS modelo Elan-

6100DRC como controles de qualidade analíticos em determinações rotineiras de 

diversos minerais de zircão. Os valores são apresentados nas Tabelas II.4 e II.5, 

respectivamente, para os materiais de referência zircão GJ-1 e zircão 91500, 

juntamente com os valores esperados para esses materiais. São apresentados os 

dados obtidos normalizados pelos valores estequiométricos de Si (ppm) e Zr (ppm). 

Quando se comparam os valores obtidos para cada um dos elementos analisados, 

utilizando-se esses dois elementos normalizadores, pode se observar que os 

resultados obtidos para Zr estequiométrico são sempre maior que os obtidos para Si 

como elemento normalizador, indicando um possível fracionamento diferente entre o 

elemento Si e os demais elementos, principalmente ETR. Dessa forma, deu-se 

preferência em comparar os dados obtidos com o elemento normalizador Zr e os 

valores recomendados. Nas Figuras II.1 e II.2 são apresentados os gráficos dos 

resultados obtidos divididos pelos valores recomendados para o zircão GJ-1 e 

91500, respectivamente, calculados pelo elemento normalizador Zr estequiométrico. 

Como pode se observar, os resultados apresentam variação dentro dos limites de 

exatidão de ± 25% do valor esperado, o que é amplamente aceito para materiais 

naturais que podem apresentar esse tipo de variabilidade.  

Para o zircão GJ-1, os elementos com variação maiores que 25% são La, Pb, 

Th e U. O elemento La apresenta-se com valores abaixo do limite de detecção. O Pb 

fornecido é apenas do isótopo 208, enquanto o valor recomendado é para chumbo 

total. Como esse elemento apresenta variabilidade entre os percentuais dos isótopos 

dependendo do decaimento de Th e U, o ideal seria somar todos os isótopos para 

fornecer o valor de chumbo total; no entanto, o software de redução de dados 

Glitter® não permite essa manobra analítica. Os valores de Th e U, bem como de 

Pb, podem apresentar alguma variabilidade dentro da estrutura do zircão devido ao 

crescimento magmático e o decaimento radioativo.

aparecem com valores dentro dos limites de ± 25% do valor esperado 

(recomendado), o que é bem aceito nesta técnica e por se tratarem de materiais 

naturais com variação química reconhecida. 

Os dados obtidos permitem implantar a metodologia utilizando o teor 

estequiométrico de Zr como elemento calibrador do padrão interno. A utilização de 

silício leva a teores mais baixos para os resultados dos elementos menores e traço 

determinados. Essa diminuição é atribuída possivelmente a comportamentos 

diferentes entre o silício e os demais elementos terras raras, HFSE e zircônio, tanto 

durante a ablação a laser, quanto propriamente no plasma, caracterizado na 

literatura como fracionamento (Jackson, 2001).

70  Tese de Doutoramento S. Andrade 

PARTE III - ASSINATURAS ISOTÓPICAS E ASPECTOS PETROGENÉTICOS 
DE GRANITOIDES DOS DOMÍNIOS EMBU, JUNDIAÍ E COSTEIRO. 

 

 

III.1. CONSIDERAÇÕES INICIAIS 

 

 

As rochas estudadas nesse trabalho são ocorrências complexas tanto do 

ponto de vista petrográfico quanto estrutural, ocorrendo como intrusões múltiplas 

com dimensões que variam de moderadas até batolíticas, e atinge até 30% da 

superfície exposta do embasamento no estado de São Paulo (Janasi; Ulbrich, 1991, 

1992). 

Nesta Tese se utilizaram as determinações multielementares em rochas e em 

minerais de zircão de granitoides presentes em várias unidades geológicas do 

Complexo Ribeira, no Estado de São Paulo, a fim de se identificar as similaridades e 

discrepâncias em teores de elementos traço. Este estudo teve como propósito 

observar padrões de evoluções petrogenéticas paralelas ou diferenciadas nas 

unidades cálcio-alcalinas e em seus derivados evoluídos.  

Como uma linha adicional de evidências, foram determinadas as razões 

isotópicas nos sistemas U-Th-Pb e Lu-Hf em zircão, além das determinações 

isotópicas Sm-Nd e Rb-Sr em rochas (os dados de razões isotópicas e discussão 

sobre aspectos petrogenéticos e tectônicos para o Domínio São Roque são 

apresentados em publicação constante do ANEXO C, Parte IV,  desta Tese; Janasi 

et al, 2015). 

A seguir são fornecidos os dados para as razões isotópicas de algumas 

rochas dos Domínios Embu, Jundiaí e Costeiro (conforme definições em Janasi; 

Ulbrich, 1991, 1992) que foram avaliados neste trabalho. 

 

 

 

 

 



 

S. Andrade Tese de Doutoramento 71

incompatíveis, derivados de minerais hidratados da crosta continental superior, é 

uma das possibilidades para se elevar essas razões iniciais de Sr, como é o caso 

dos granitos Tico-Tico e São Roque que apresentam valores entre 0.713-0.720.

A relação Sm/Nd de rochas crustais não é modificada por eventos como 

metamorfismo, erosão ou redeposição (Faure, 1986). As idades modelo em Nd 



 

S. Andrade Tese de Doutoramento 73 

podem ser interpretadas como o tempo de residência da rocha na crosta. Dessa 

forma pode se inferir pelos dados de Nd(TDM) que o magma parental dos granitos 

Itaquera (ITA-2), São Roque (SR-07) e Itaqui (ITQ-2) se diferenciou do manto 

superior a cerca de 2.0 Ga, assim como o Granito Cantareira (Tassinari,1988). A 

amostra CHA-1 (charnockito) mostra uma idade modelo em torno de 1600 Ma e o 

?Nd(0) indica se tratar de uma rocha com protólito de idade fanerozóica. 

 

 

III.3. RAZÕES ISOTÓPICAS U-Th-Pb  E Lu-Hf DE GRANITOIDES DOS 

DOMÍNIOS EMBU, COSTEIRO E JUNDIAI E COMPARAÇÃO COM OS DO 

DOMÍNIO SÃO ROQUE. 

 

 

Os dados das razões U-Th-Pb e Lu-Hf obtidos para os minerais de zircão dos 

granitos do Domínio São Roque (São Roque, Taipas, Itaqui, Tico-Tico, Perus e 

Cantareira) foram publicados em Janasi et al (2015), assim como os dados de 

datação para o granitoide Ilha Anchieta (IA-10D) em Azevedo Sobrinho et al (2011), 

com as respectivas discussões sobre as implicações petrogenéticas e tectônicas. A 

seguir serão apresentados os dados isotópicos de U-Th-Pb para as amostras de 

zircão dos granitos de Itaquera, Itu, Terra Nova e do charnockito de Ubatuba, e 

possíveis correlações com os granitos do Domínio São Roque, assim como os 

dados de Lu-Hf para essas amostras e também para Ilha Anchieta.  

Os dados isotópicos U-Th-Pb para zircões do Granito Itaquera (amostra ITA-

2) pertencente ao Domínio Embu, dos granitos Itu e Terra Nova (ITU-14X e TN-1), 

pertencentes ao Domínio Jundiaí, e do charnockito Ubatuba (amostras CHA-1) do 

Domínio Costeiro, são apresentados na Tabela TS-1 (Dados Suplementares, Parte 

V), bem como os diagramas de concórdia com as respectivas idades de cristalização 

na Figura FS-1 (Dados Suplementares, Parte V). Imagens de catodoluminescência 

dos zircões analisados com os respectivos pontos amostrados são apresentados na 

Figura FS-2 (Dados Suplementares, Parte V). 

A amostra ITU-14X teve 13 zircões amostrados por SHRIMP e utilizados para 

a obtenção da idade em 591±28 Ma (MSWD de 1.18), através da interceptação da 

linha de concórdia, pois não foi possível obter um grupo coerente de amostras para 



 

74  Tese de Doutoramento S. Andrade 

obtenção dessa idade. A amostra TN-1 teve 16 pontos de zircão amostrados por 

Shrimp usando o mesmo procedimento de interceptação da linha de concórdia para 

obter-se a idade provável de cristalização de 579±12 Ma (MSWD = 0.38), devido 

também a impossibilidade de se obter um grupo coerente de amostras.  

Na amostra ITA-2 do Granito Itaquera foram analisados por Shrimp 15 pontos 

e foram descartados três pontos devido aos elevados teores de chumbo comum 

(
204

Pb) e também um zircão com elevado teor de U; a idade obtida por concórdia 

(91% de probabilidade) para os 11 pontos restantes foi de 593.5±4.4 Ma 

(MSWM=0.013). 

No charnockito Ubatuba (CHA-1) foram analisados por Shrimp 14 zircões e 

apenas um foi descartado devido à baixa relação Th/U. A idade concórdia para 

cristalização do granitoide foi de 582.4±4.8 Ma (MSWM=0.013). 

Comparando-se esses dados dos granitos do Domínio São Roque (amostras: 

Cant-6; MD-42B, ”satélite” do Cantareira; SR-07, São Roque; ITQ-2, Itaqui; MD-24, 

“satélite” do Itaqui; TAP-1, Taipas; Tico-2) com os obtidos para as amostras Itu-14X 

(Itu), TN-1 (Terra Nova) e ITA-2 (Itaquera) se observa que as idades são muito 

próximas, com exceção de TN-1, possivelmente devido à discórdia entre os dados 

U-Th-Pb. O charnockito de Ubatuba, que também apresenta idade de cristalização 

menor que o grupo analisado, mostra coerência com os dados obtidos anteriormente 

por Heilbron; Machado (2003) para os terrenos sin-colisionais orientais do Domínio 

Costeiro, e por Gasparini; Mantovani (1979) para os leucogranitos associados ao 

Charnockito Ubatuba (~565 Ma), uma vez que tanto o granito de Ilha Anchieta 

(499.7±5.9 Ma; Azevedo Sobrinho et al, 2011) como os leucogranitos são intrusivos 

no  Charnockito Ubatuba. 

Todos os zircões analisados para o domínio Embu, Jundiaí e Costeiro 

mostraram idades de cristalização no intervalo de 594 a 579 Ma, sobrepondo-se as 

idades de cristalização dos granitos mais jovens (e.g. Tico-Tico, amostra Tico-2) e 

“satélite” Cantareira (MD-42B) do domínio São Roque, que variam de 594 a 590 Ma 

(Janasi et al, 2015).  

Os dados de Lu-Hf obtidos em zircão por LA-HR-ICPMS para as amostras 

dos granitos Itu (ITU-14X), Terra Nova (TN-1), Itaquera (ITA-2), Ilha Anchieta (IA-

10D) e Charnockito Ubatuba (CHA-1) são apresentados na Tabela TS-2 (ver Dados 



 

S. Andrade Tese de Doutoramento 75 

Suplementares, Parte V). Os granitos do Domínio São Roque são descritos e 

discutidos por Janasi et al (2015; ver Parte IV).  

A composição isotópica Lu-Hf foi obtida e avaliada para a amostra ITA-2 

(Itaquera – Domínio Embu) pelo fator ?Hf (594 Ma), que mostra uma estreita variação 

de 2 unidades de ?Hf dentro do intervalo de -21.8 à -23.8, com média e desvio padrão 

de -22.7±0.7. Este valor é muito similar ao encontrado para a amostra SR-07 (São 

Roque-Domínio São Roque), com ?Hf (603 Ma) de -21 à -24 e média de -22.8±1.2, 

valor próximo ao encontrado para a amostra ITQ-2 (-19 à -20), com média de -17.4 

±1.4, todas com característica de rochas derivadas de magmas crustais evoluídos 

(?Hf muito negativo). Para a amostra ITA-2, um zircão analisado mostrou ?Hf(T1) de -

10.5, indicando possivelmente uma mistura com protólitos mais radiogênicos ou 

menos evoluídos, semelhantes ao encontrado para o enclave de Itaqui (ITQ-E), cujo 

?Hf (594 Ma)  variou de -11 à -12. 

As amostras TN-1 (Terra Nova) e ITU-14X, provenientes do Domínio Jundiaí, 

mostram valores de ?Hf (T1) muito próximos entre si: TN-1 de -8.3 à -13.3 (média de -

10.8±2.0) e Itu-14X de -8.1 a -14.8 (média de -11.3±1.8) e, também, com uma ampla 

variação nos valores de ?Hf (média de 5 unidades), indicando se tratar de fonte 

menos homogênea que as observadas para ITA-2 e SR-07. Nas amostras TN-1 e 

ITU-14X, alguns zircões analisados mostram valores de ?Hf (T1) mais negativos que 

as médias determinadas para essas amostras (-16.8 e -17.7, respectivamente), 

indicando uma provável interação com protólitos mais evoluídos. Os dados de ?Hf 

(T1) para as amostras TN-1 e ITU-14X estão no mesmo intervalo daqueles 

observados para as amostras de granitos provenientes do Domínio São Roque, MD-

42B (“satélite” do Cantareira), TAP-1 (Taipas) e Tico-2 (Tico-Tico), cujos intervalos 

de variação do ?Hf (T1) se encontram, respectivamente, na faixa de -9.5 a -12, de -

10.5 a -14 e de -10.5 a -12. Em um zircão da amostra TN-1 foi encontrado ?Hf (T1) 

de -0.48, indicando alguma interação com restitos mais radiogênicos. 

As amostras de granitoides provenientes do Domínio Costeiro CHA-1 

(charnockito) e IA-10D (Ilha Anchieta) mostram ampla variação do ?Hf (T1), chegando 

a mais  de 5 unidades de ?Hf para o Charnockito de Ubatuba (-2.2  à -6.7,  média de 

-4.4 ± 1.3), enquanto para IA-10D os valores estão na faixa de -4.3 à -7.8 (média de 

-6.2±1.2). Em ambas as amostras observa-se um caráter crustal menos evoluído 



 

76  Tese de Doutoramento S. Andrade 

quando comparados às demais amostras, principalmente para o Charnockito 

Ubatuba, indicando alguma mistura com fontes mais mantélicas e radiogênicas.  

Para uma discussão das possíveis fontes dos granitos estudados nesta Tese 

serão consideradas as razões de Lu/Hf comumente utilizadas na literatura para a 

crosta intermediária (0.015) (Vervoort et al, 1999). Na Tabela III.2 é apresentado um 

resumo das idades obtidas através dos dados isotópicos de U-Th-Pb, dos valores de 

?Hf (T1) e idade TDM obtidos pelo método de Lu-Hf, além dos dados de ?Nd(T1) e 

idade TDM obtidas através das razões Sm/Nd para as amostras do Domínio São 

Roque, Embu, Jundiaí e Costeiro. Na Figura III.1 pode ser visualizado o diagrama de 

?Hf versus tempo (Ma) para os granitos São Roque, Taipas, Tico-Tico e Satélite 

Cantareira do Domínio São Roque, Terra Nova e Itu do Domínio Jundiaí e Itaquera 

do Domínio Embu, além da curva para o manto empobrecido. A extrapolação das 

curvas de evolução para o tempo anterior à geração dos granitos foi calculada 

utilizando o valor para a relação 
176

Lu/
177

Hf de 0.015, que corresponde a crosta 

intermediária.

satélite Cantareira do Domínio São Roque, Terra Nova e Itu do Domínio Jundiaí e Itaquera 
do Domínio Embu.

provenientes do Domínio Costeiro.

83 

 

An examination of selected granitoid occurrences in the São Paulo Ribeira 

Belt: trace element abundances in zircon as petrogenetic indicators 

 

Andrade, S.*; Ulbrich, H.H.G.J.; Janasi, V.A. 

 

Departamento de Mineralogia e Geotectônica - Instituto de Geociências - USP 

* Corresponding author - E-mail address:  sandrade@usp.br 

 

ABSTRACT 

Mass spectrometry with inductively coupled plasma associated with laser 
ablation (LA-ICPMS) is a powerful tool that allows analytical determinations of trace 
elements, with high sensitivity and resolution, in zircon and other accessory minerals. 
This study is a contribution to the knowledge of zircon compositions derived from 
granitic rocks belonging to the Brasiliano cycle of granite magma genesis in the 
basement areas of São Paulo state (conveniently divided into “domains”), in 
southeastern Brazil. Sampled granites in the São Roque Domain are the São Roque, 
Cantareira and Itaqui batholiths, the Perus and Taipas granites and the Tico-Tico 
intrusion. The Itu batholith and the Terra Nova intrusion are found in the Jundiaí 
Domain, while the Itaquera samples outcrop in the Embu Domain. Samples from the 
Ubatuba charnockite and the Ilha Anchieta site belong to the Coastal (Costeiro) 
Domain. 

A preliminary discussion on the contrasted geochemical characteristics is 
offered for the entire set of samples, identifying chemical parameters that help to 
define the different granite lineages (e.g., peraluminous or peralkaline character, 
identification of “I”, “S” or “A” types of granitoids, etc.). Zircons extracted from these 
granite samples present usually elevated contents of REE, Th and U, with positive 
Ce and sometimes negative Eu anomalies (Tico-Tico, Itu, Terra Nova, Itaquera, Ilha 
Anchieta, Ubatuba charnockite and Perus tourmaline granite). High abundances of 
REE+Y in the analyzed zircons could be created by coupled reactions that occur 
during zircon crystallization, with substitutions of Si

4+
 by P

5+

4+

3+

3+

ratios in general are close to 0.5, expected for zircons of magmatic origin, some 
grains however presenting values close to 0.1, attesting to a decrease in Th contents 
probably generated by co-crystallization of the mineral with monazite. Comparison of 
U/Yb ratios with Hf contents show that the analyzed zircons were generated in a 
crustal-continental environment. The model Ti-in-zircon geothermometer, determined 
in zircons with typical magmatic growth textures (e.g., oscillatory zoning overgrowth 
on idiomorphic cores) yielded reasonable crystallization temperature estimates in 
comparison with the ones estimated with the zircon and apatite saturation model 
temperatures in magmas. 

Zircons presenting unusual textures (e.g., cores with irregular margins, 
identifying possible resorption of relicts, or very dark colors under 



 

84 

 

cathodoluminescence) led to unrealistic temperature estimates of over 1000
o
C. 

Positive correlations in Ti versus REE diagrams indicate that an increase in Ti in 
zircons and, consequently, an increase in their model temperatures of crystallization, 
can actually be associated with significant substitutions, in zircons, of Zr by Ti, as well 
as by Si. The same zircon grains also show a remarkable increase in contents of Nb, 
Ta and P, with positive correlation when compared with (REE + Y) contents, 
suggesting that these increases in the abundances of those elements (including also 
Ti) can be a sign of hydrothermal fluid activity during zircon (re)-crystallizations, fluids 
that are possibly also enriched in halides, alkalies, silica and CO2. Fluid activity 
during granite magma crystallization may have been channeled through existing 
favorable structures, such as the shear zones ubiquitously present in the Ribeira 
Belt. 
 

Key Words: LA-ICPMS, zircon chemistry, trace elements in zircons, petrogenetic 
indicators, hydrothermal fluids, Brasiliano granites.  

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 



 

85 

 

1. INTRODUCTION 

 

Zircon is ubiquitously present as an accessory mineral especially in granitoids, 

as well as in mantle rocks, meteorites and lunar samples (e.g., Page et al. 2007; Liu 

et al. 2010). It has been shown that this mineral preserves in its structure and 

composition a remarkable memory of previous developments, including its first 

crystallization, as well as ulterior crystallizations, present as external growth zones, 

with trace elements occupying the sites of Si and Zr in the zircon crystal, the input in 

its structure tightly controlled by environmental variables, such as ion activities, 

temperatures, and pressures. Another important characteristic of this mineral is its 

strong resilience at high temperatures and pressures, typically observed in processes 

of metamorphism, avoiding an elemental and isotopic diffusive rebalancing in those 

conditions (Watson, 1996; Watson and Cherniak, 1997).  

Zircon, even being an accessory phase, strongly controls the distribution of 

many trace elements especially in granitic rocks, since it is by structural design and 

chemistry the natural  holder of various trace elements, which have a tendency to 

exchange place with Si and/or Zr (Belousova et al. 2002), especially when 

crystallizing from magmas (e.g., Murali et al. 1983). Studies centered on zircon 

chemistry provide clues about the composition and nature of original parental 

magmas (e.g., Robatto 2002) and source protoliths and crystallization environment 

(e.g. Nardi et al. 2012, Trail et al. 2012), as well as indicating genetic granite types 

(whether type I, S, or A), also pinpointing solidification temperatures, in particular with 

the use of the recently proposed Ti-in-zircon geothermometry (Watson & Harrison 

2005; Harrison et al. 2007). 

In granitoid rocks, REE abundances, mostly incorporated into accessory 

minerals (foremost in zircon, titanite, allanite, and xenotime), diminish with 

progressive differentiation, as clearly observed in compositions of granitic magmas in 

these series, without however generating a significant change in the pattern of REE 

distribution, from the parental liquids up to the more evolved granitic magmas. 

The possibility to study the presence and abundance of REE and other trace 

elements especially in accessory minerals can be performed today with the use of 

Laser Ablation (LA) techniques applied to single crystals separated from their host 



 

86 

 

rock. Our study selected zircons contained in several Brasiliano granitoids 

occurrences, representing various types occurring in the basement areas of São 

Paulo state, to obtain data on trace element incorporation, to provide new 

interpretations relying heavily on considerations that this new chemical technique can 

bring to this subject. 

The basement areas of the state of São Paulo, southeastern Brazil, is mostly 

made up by a large variety of metamorphic rocks, ranging from low-grade 

metamorphic facies (e.g., São Roque group of rocks) to terrains where high-grade 

types are predominant (e.g., Ubatuba charnockites). A remarkable feature of this 

basement region is the presence of large amounts of granitoids occurrences, mostly 

referred to the activity of the so-called Brasiliano cycle of tectonics, metamorphism, 

and magmatism. These granitoids were grouped in earlier studies mostly according 

to their shape and/or deformation pattern, as: 1) pre-orogenic types, mostly 

represented by strongly deformed bodies; 2) syn-orogenic ones recognized by their 

elongated shape with a NE-SW direction, the predominant structural trend in SE 

Brazil, and 3) late- to post-orogenic massifs, mostly represented by undeformed 

bodies with a tendency to form broadly equidimensional to rounded outcrops 

patterns. More recent studies, performed in the 80’s and 90’s, clarified aspects by 

mapping in detail many of these bodies, adding data to show the extreme complexity 

of most of them (e.g., batholiths such as Cantareira, São Roque, Itu, Itaqui and 

Morungaba), as well as smaller bodies such as the ones outcropping in Piedade, 

Piracaia and Perus (Taipas, Tico-Tico, etc.).  

The method of study adopted in this paper, given the extraordinary complexity 

of the granite geology in the state of São Paulo, was to select some rather distinct 

samples representing many granitic bodies, also based on the knowledge gained in 

the last decades about these rocks in our state. Thus, an admittedly biased group of 

samples was selected, a bias that can be explained because the knowledge about 

the respective granitic bodies, as well as about the regional context, was vastly 

increased in the last few years, on account of research activities heavily relying on 

chemical and isotopic determinations with a modern bias. Whenever possible, given 

the poor outcrop pattern that is the common rule in São Paulo state, fresh and large 



 

87 

 

samples were obtained from quarries and larger road cuts, later used in chemical 

studies and providing the materials for extraction of zircon single crystals.  

 

2. GEOLOGICAL FRAMEWORK 

 

The basement area outcropping in the state of São Paulo comprises two 

different types of rocks, one being the country rocks developed through complex 

phenomena during geologic history, beginning with sedimentation and following with 

a protracted sequence of deformation and metamorphism, constituting several still 

incompletely defined basement “complexes”, in part also invaded by older (pre-

Brasiliano) granites, now heavily deformed, in turn cut by a bewildering variety of 

later granitic magmas, occupying about 30% of the exposed basement areas. This 

late granitic plutonic activity, generally referred to as the “Brasiliano event”, lasted 

from about 600 Ma to about 480-450 Ma, encompassing all types of granitic plutons, 

some clearly early- or syn-tectonic occurrences usually defined by their elongated 

oriented form, and also others that are clearly representing late tectonic or even post-

tectonic occurrences. 

A very prominent feature in this basement region, as in the entire section 

covering southeastern and southern Brazil, is the presence of shear zones of 

regional extent, all bearing a predominant NE-SW direction, therefore providing the 

possibility to divide these basement areas into several “domains”. Such a domain 

map for the state of São Paulo is presented in Figure 1 (source: Janasi & Ulbrich, 

1992;), showing the positions of the numerous granitic occurrences conveniently 

divided up into pre-tectonic occurrences (deformed, mainly converted into gneisses), 

“dry” granitoids (charnockites and magnerites), syn- to late tectonic bodies (the 

predominant type, including nebulitic occurrences as well as porphyritic to 

equigranular granites of several ancestries, referred to as “I” and “S” type granitoids) 

and post-tectonic (“post-orogenic”) varieties (for a more recent outline of the “domain” 

structure of the basement areas in SE Brazil, cf. Janasi et al., 2015, and bibliography 

cited therein). The noteworthy NE-SW structural trend observed in Figure 1, very 

marked in S-SE Brazil and controlled by the direction followed by the predominant 

regional shear fracture zones and notably represented by the arrangement and form 



 

88 

 

of several granitic bodies, allows also to propose for this basement region a “domain” 

structure with limits between the different basement units given by the most 

prominent shear zones. The recognized domains (in Janasi & Ulbrich 1992; cf. also 

Janasi et al., 2015), which mostly continue into the neighboring states of Paraná (to 

the south and southwest) and Rio de Janeiro and Minas Gerais (to the north and 

northeast), are named as follow: the Iguape and Ubatuba domains (coastal units), 

Açungui and Embu domains (projecting into Parana state, the last one farther north 

into Rio de Janeiro), the thin slice of the São Roque domain, and also the Amparo, 

Jundiaí and Guaxupé units. The western limits are given by the outcrops of the 

Paraná basin strata covering basement rocks (Figure 1). 

The granitic bodies sampled in our study are indicated in Figure 1. In the São 

Roque domain, the selected massifs were the Itaqui, São Roque and Cantareira 

batholiths, the Taipas stocks and the Tico-Tico intrusion, as well as a stock belonging 

to the group of the Perus tourmaline granites. The Itu batholith and the Terra Nova 

intrusion are located within the Jundiai domain, while the Itaquera outcrops, 

positioned within the Embu domain, are now virtually inaccessible because of their 

location in the eastern boroughs of the capital city of São Paulo. The Ubatuba 

occurrences of “dry” granitic types are located within the Ubatuba domain, together 

with the Ilha Anchieta sample, the last one an island occurrence.  

A more detailed map of part of the São Roque domain is shown in Figure 2, 

indicating the positions of the Cantareira and Itaqui batholiths, as well as those of the 

three Taipas stocks and the Tico-Tico intrusion, and also the area in which the 

several bodies of the Perus tourmaline granites are found (compilation map by 

Azevedo, 1997).

3. THE SAMPLED GRANITOID OCCURRENCES 

 

A brief description of the several sampled granitic occurrences is given here, 

as a reference framework to show the complexities found in the several Brasiliano 

granite intrusions (for previous references, see Janasi & Ulbrich, 1992; also Azevedo 

1997 and Janasi et al. 2015, for additional bibliography and a summary of geological 

features).  

 

3a. Occurrences in the São Roque Domain  

The granites sampled in the São Roque domain (as defined in Janasi & 

Ulbrich, 1992; Figure 1) come from the following occurrences: Cantareira batholith, 

Taipas stocks, Perus tourmaline granitoids, Itaqui and São Roque batholiths, the 

Tico-Tico intrusion. 

 

Cantareira batholith 

This intrusion, studied mainly by Dantas (1990), is one of the largest granitic 

bodies exposed in the state of São Paulo, covering about 320 km
2
. It is broadly 

elongated along the regionally predominant NE-SW direction. Contacts are mainly 

tectonic, limited mostly by the Caieiras (northern part) and Mandaqui (western limit) 

shear zones. Nine predominant facial types were recognized in the batholith. The 

Pirituba facies (cream-colored massive porphyroid type), the Canivete unit (bluish 

grey porphyroid facies) and the Itaguassu type (porphyroid rosy facies) are mostly 

biotite granodiorites and monzogranites, predominant in the central and SE part of 

the massif (Pirituba) and to the SW (Canivete) and scattered within the entire massif 

as irregular masses (Itaguassu), presenting mostly non-oriented K-feldspar 

megacrysts and biotite, with little hornblende, as main mafic phase ; all show several 

types of enclaves. The Mandaqui type (orthognaissic facies), porphyroid granodioritic 

to monzogranitic in composition, shows rounded megacrysts of K-feldspar set in a 

groundmass with mylonitic to blastomylonitic texture, restricted to locations along 

outer contacts and along fault zones cutting the batholith. The Tremembé type (grey 

equigranular facies) appears as grey monzogranite concentrations with enclaves in 

dykes and irregular smaller bodies distributed all along the batholith. The Petrópolis 

type (pegmatoid facies) constitutes smaller irregular masses of granodiorites to 



 

92 

 

monzogranites, with plenty of K-feldspar phenocrysts and presence of microgranular 

and micaceous enclaves. The Hortolândia type (grey inequigranular facies) shows 

inequigranular monzogranites to granodiorites, with an oriented texture and presence 

of enclaves, found along the NE contact zone, grading into porphyroid facies. The 

Santa Inês type (migmatitic or banded facies) is made up of porphyroid granodiorites 

with plenty of biotite and an oriented (flow?) structure, found mainly along the N 

border. The Jaraguá type (leucocratic equigranular facies) is present as irregular 

concentrations and dikes of leuco-quartz monzonites, sometimes appearing with a 

marked hydrothermal alteration. Dantas (1990) positions the entire magmatic activity 

as synchronous to the D2 deformation phase observed in the metamorphic country 

rocks (São Roque Complex s.l.). Wernick et al. (1993) recognize four distinct 

magmatic pulses as the cause for the emplacement of the batholith. 

 

Taipas stocks 

Azevedo (1997) found that the Taipas massif, formerly mapped as a larger 

stock, has to be divided into three separate intrusions, petrographically very similar to 

each other and to the Pirituba facies in the Cantareira body. These stocks are 

located close to the southwestern border of Cantareira (Figure 2). Porphyritic 

textures (with K-feldspar megacrysts) are predominant in these monzogranites (to 

granodiorites and tonalites). 

 

Perus tourmaline granitoids 

Outcropping in an area immediately to the west of the Cantareira massif, these 

rocks appear as dikes and some small stocks, not larger in dimension than 100 to 

200 m, sustaining quarrying activities in the immediate past. The rocks have as a 

common feature the presence of tourmaline, as well as the complete absence of 

biotite. These occurrences caught the attention of geologist and mineralogists in the 

past on account of the presence of tourmaline, as well as of other rare minerals (cf. 

Azevedo, 1997, for a bibliography on this subject). The occurrences were mapped 

and studied more recently in detail by Azevedo (1997), who recognized several 

facies types. The one which is predominant in the stocks is a remarkable layered 

facies. Each layer, with a thickness not surpassing a few cm, appears in association 

with other similar layers, thus repeating structures such as the ones observed in the 



 

93 

 

remarkable basaltic stratiform intrusions. The layers appear deformed and folded, 

possibly on account of a syn-magmatic deformation generated by the still active 

shear zones on the layered sequences present as a crystallizing magmatic mush (cf. 

Azevedo, 1997, and discussion therein). The most common structure is the one 

where each layer shows a rapid gradation between the lower and middle parts, 

presenting variations in the contents of feldspars and quartz, and lesser amounts of 

tourmaline, which usually concentrates in the upper level; other distributions were 

also found, such as the one where tourmaline concentrates in the lower level, a much 

rarer case. A non-layered homogenous facies, also described, is much rarer. A 

pegmatitic facies is also present, especially in the stocks, where this type can occupy 

as much as 20 to 40% of the quarried central areas (the internal pegmatitic facies of 

Azevedo, 1997). Many of the dikes outcropping in the same region are entirely made 

up of tourmaline pegmatites, genetically related with the layered granites (the 

external pegmatitic facies of Azevedo 1997).  

 

Itaqui batholith 

This multiple intrusion was mapped in detail by Ferreira (1991, 1997). It shows 

a broadly triangular form, covering around 120 km
2
, cut in its southern part by the 

Taxaquara shear zone. The first intrusions are those of the porphyroid granodioritic 

Barueri and the monzogranitic Pedreira Cantareira unit, both with biotite and 

hornblende. The following intrusions are the dikes of the Torre equigranular biotite 

monzogranite and the Cruz Preta porphyroid biotite quartz monzonite. A third phase 

of intrusions is represented by the biotite monzogranites of the Aldeia da Serra and 

Mutinga stocks, respectively positioned at the southwestern and southeastern part of 

the batholith. A last intrusive phase is represented by the dikes of the Suru 

monzogranites and some tourmaline aplites.  

 

São Roque batholith 

This batholith, broadly triangular in shape and covering a surface of roughly 

160 km
2
, was mapped in detail by Coutinho (1953) and later by Andrade (1993). 

Contacts are tectonic, to the south, at the base of the triangle, with the Taxaquara 

fault, to the west with the Mairinque fault along 38 km, and to the east, showing an 

arcuate shape with the Araçariguama shear zone. It is, both petrographically and 



 

94 

 

structurally, similar to the Itaqui batholith, however presenting small pockets of 

intrusions of tourmaline granites, absent in the Itaqui body (Andrade 1993; Wernick 

et al. 1995a). Clusters of pegmatitic smaller bodies are commonly distributed both 

through the more equigranular as well as in the porphyroid facies, constituted mainly 

by euhedral to subhedral K-feldspar crystals.  

 

Tico-Tico intrusion 

This intrusion, studied earlier by Moraes Rego (1933) and renamed 

Anhanguera in a later study by Penalva & Hasui (1970), is an elongated body 

covering about 11 km
2
, with a general east-west orientation. The main components 

are inequigranular syeno- to monzogranites, with biotite and magmatic muscovite, 

garnet, some tourmaline and plenty of zircon; structure is generally massive, 

sometimes also showing a weak planar orientation. Deformed pegmatitic veins and 

dikes with a granitic composition are also found, presenting tourmaline 

concentrations in its central part, accompanied by muscovite crystallization along the 

contact with the metamorphic country rocks. It is classified as a late-tectonic 

granitoid. 

 

 

3b. Occurrences in the Jundiaí Domain.  

 

The Itu batholith and the Terra Nova intrusions are both positioned within the 

Jundiaí domain (Figure 1), which forms a part of the so-called Median Guaxupé 

Massif, constituted by quartzites, schists and gneisses (frequently migmatitic), 

pertaining possibly entirely to the tectono-metamorphic pre-Brasiliano Piracaia 

complex  (Campos Neto et al. 1983). 

 

Itu batholith 

It is the largest granitic body mapped in the Jundiaí domain, covering around 

390 km
2
, of which over 200 km

2
 can be easily visualized, mainly appearing as large 

boulder fields and horizontal flat-lying exposures. It is formed mainly by the three 

separate intrusions named Salto, Cabreúva and Indaiatuba that, in part, present 

texturally features reminiscent of rapakivi facies (e.g., large sub-rounded to sub-



 

95 

 

idiomorphic K-feldspars megacrysts, sometimes also showing plagioclase mantling a 

core feldspar) and of other, less characteristic type-A calc-alkaline intrusions, such as 

the Itupeva body. Both equigranular as well as porphyritic biotite syenogranites are 

the predominant varieties in the rapakivi facies, all of them showing abundant 

accessory zircon (see Galembeck 1991, Galembeck et al. 1991, Wernick et al. 

1995b). 

 

Terra Nova intrusion 

It is found within the Jundiaí domain (Figure 1), which forms a part of the so-

called Median Guaxupé Massif, constituted by quartzites, schists and gneisses 

(frequently migmatitic), pertaining possibly entirely to the tectono-metamorphic pre-

Brasiliano Piracaia Complex (Campos Neto et al. 1983). The granitic massif itself 

covers about 23 km
2
, presenting an irregular form, partly elongated in a NE direction. 

It is constituted mainly by rosy-colored equigranular biotite granites, which may show 

locally along its borders an oriented grey granite (Hasui et al., 1978). Biotite is the 

predominant mafic mineral, with sodic amphibole in the rosy facies, while common 

hornblende is present in the grey granite.  

 

3c. Occurrences in the Embu Domain 

 

The central part of the Embu Domain is almost entirely covered by the city of 

São Paulo and surrounding areas, and the definitions of the described granite 

occurrences rely heavily on earlier work. 

 

Itaquera intrusion 

Although now almost completely destroyed and covered by urban 

development, a few inactive former quarries can still be sampled, showing some 

good examples of this rock, known commercially as the “Itaquera granite”, borrowing 

its name from the geographic locality, in the last years made famous as the name of 

the stadium which is host to one of the most popular football teams in São Paulo. 

The granite is a two-mica, mainly equigranular facies, which according to one earlier 

report forms a rectangular body, 14 x 3 km, about 40 km
2
 in size (represented as 

such in IPT 1981, the official map of the state of São Paulo), while other authors 



 

96 

 

restrict its size to no more than 2 km
2
, supposedly presenting gradations towards 

tonalitic gneisses with garnet and muscovite (see Janasi & Ulbrich, 1992). 

 

3d. Occurrences in the Ubatuba Domain  

 

The Neoproterozoic Ribeira Belt in SE Brazil is represented by different 

geologic domains in SE São Paulo, developed around the SE border of the São 

Francisco craton, as a consequence of convergence with another plate positioned to 

the East (Brito Neves et al., 1999; Heilbron & Machado 2003). The Rio Negro 

magmatic arc was formed at that time and accreted against the São Francisco 

continent by means of a frontal collision around 590 to 550 Ma ago. Two main 

geologic domains can be distinguished in the Ribeira belt in São Paulo, the first one 

known as the Embu domain (mainly formed by supracrustal metamorphic rocks with 

a medium grade, deformed and metamorphosed around 800 Ma ago, followed by 

several granite intrusions, of which one dated around 600 to 580 Ma is the more 

remarkable (Janasi et al. 2003). The other unit is the Coastal (Ubatuba) domain, 

made up of granitic and orthogneissic rocks, with some higher grade migmatites. 

Rocks of the Ubatuba domain are relatively younger than the ones in the Embu 

domain, presenting Sm-Nd ages of less than 1.5 Ga, in comparison to Sm-Nd ages 

of 2.0 Ga detected in the Embu domain. The igneous rocks in the Coastal (Ubatuba) 

domain show a higher-grade metamorphism, evolved around 590 Ma, an age that 

coincides with the ones determined for some syn-orogenic correlated granitoids (e.g., 

the Natividade da Serra elongated batholith presenting two-mica granites; Janasi et 

al., 2003).  

 

Ubatuba granitoids 

These granitoids, petrographically quartz mangerites to charnockites, are 

observed in association with some local dioritc bodies; they are usually deformed and 

present a secondary foliation, but may also be found as non-deformed intrusions, as 

observed in several poorly-known occurrences, such as the Guarujá Granite (Dias 

Neto et al. 2008) and the Santos body (Silva et al. 2005). They are mostly 

inequigranular, medium- to coarse-grained, characterized by greenish-grey colors. 



 

97 

 

Associated leucogranites are similar in texture and deformation, but are rosy to 

reddish in color, with minor amounts of mafic minerals (CI around 4-5). 

 

Ilha Anchieta granitoids  

These rocks outcrop on an inland with a general triangular form, mainly 

occupied by several granitoids facies (Janasi & Ulbrich, 1992). To the NE and NW, 

augengneisses are observed, while charnockites and leucogranites appear as a N-S 

trending strip, 2 km wide, in the western part of the island. Quartz monzonites are 

also observed in other areas.  

 

4. PETROGRAPHY OF THE GRANITOID ROCKS

Cantareira and Taipas. One Cantareira rock (Cant-6, porphyrytic biotite 

monzogranite representing the Pirituba facies (Figure 3a), cf. Dantas, 1990) was 

collected within the Basalto quarry (Av. Raimundo Pereira de Magalhães, 2547 - 

close to the Mario Covas “Rodoanel”; cf. Figure 2). A second Cantareira sample, MD-

42B, comes from a satellite body from a highway cut at the Bandeirantes Highway 

(close to km 26), representing an inequigranular syenogranite of the Canivete facies 

of Dantas (1990). Sample Cant-6 (Figure 3b) presents a porphyritic texture, with 

large microcline grains with Carlsbad twinning associated with plagioclase and 

surrounded by quartz; CI is around 10 to 20. K-feldspar is almost without perthites, 

somewhat altered to sericite, with idiomorphic to irregular inclusions of altered 

plagioclase, with reaction rims, as well as inclusions of biotite and opaque minerals. 

The plagioclase is altered (to sericite), also showing titanite and epidote. Quartz is 

deformed and shows mosaic structure and undulatory extinction. Mafics are 

distributed in a uniform manner. Biotite, mostly deformed, and amphibole are 

greenish-brown. The main accessory minerals are zircon, titanite, apatite, and 

opaques (magnetite).

In the Polimix quarry, sheared very thin rock slices are frequently observed,

4d. “Dry” granites in the Ubatuba domain: Ubatuba, Ilha Anchieta.  

Two samples of granitoids, one of them a representative of a “dry” facies (a 

charnockite), were collected in the Ubatuba domain. 

 

Ubatuba charnockite. The sample (CHA-1) was collected in an abandoned 

quarry named Pedreira Itamambuca, close to the km 36 of the Rio-Santos highway 

(BR-101), 13 km north of Ubatuba city at the Itamambuca beach. It is a grey-greenish 

rock, extremely fresh, coarse-grained with mafic cm-sized aggregates; CI is around 

10-15 (Figures 15a, 15b). K-feldspar is fresh, homogeneous (no twins) and with only 

some tiny perthites appearing in sectors of the host grain; optically, it is an 

orthoclase, frequently presenting plagioclase inclusions. Plagioclase presents very 

fine twins, no alteration, and also some antiperthites (irregular to square patches). 

Quartz shows a variety of sizes, appears in mosaics, with ondulatory extinction. 

Accessory minerals are zircon, opaques, apatite; no titanite was observed. The mafic 

aggregates show mainly brown amphibole with irregular outlines, with pleochroism 

from dark brown (almost opaque) to yellowish-brown. Pyroxenes are important 

additions, the clinopyroxene appearing as extremely irregular, mostly elongated 

grains, with a faint greenish, slightly pleochroic color. Orthopyroxene is intergrown 

with the monoclinic variety, appearing again as very irregular grains, clear colors, 

with inclusions (apatite, opaques, and plagioclase). Biotite is subordinate, mostly 

associated with amphibole, presenting a pleochroism from brownish-orange to very 

dark brown (Figures 16a, 16b).

5. ANALYTICAL METHODS 

 

A brief description of the several chemical methods used to identify the 

compositional parameters is here offered. A more detailed treatment can be found in 

selected papers dealing with the methodological aspects, also cited in the following 

lines.  

 

5.1. Whole-rock geochemistry: major, minor and trace element 

determinations  

 

X-ray Fluorescent technique (XRF) is mainly used for the determination of 

major, minor and some trace elements in rocks. The technique begins with the 

selection of mainly clean and unaltered samples (typically, several kg), then 

fragmentation followed by grinding to small grain sizes (less than 200 mesh) that 

allow easy  preparation of pressed pellets and fused–glass samples (cf. details in 

Mori et al., 1999). The determinations were realized with a Philips spectrometer 

model PW2400, with a Mo tube and an automatic sampler, at the XRF Laboratory of 

the recently created NAP-Geoanalítica facility at Instituto de Geociências - USP. 

Issues related to contamination during preparation of powdered samples are 

addressed and discussed in detail in Sertek et al. (2015).  

 

5.2. Whole-rock geochemistry: determination of REE and other trace 

elements with ICP-MS. 

 

The used methodology to determine the abundances of rare earth elements 

and other trace elements relies on a quadrupole ICP-MS spectrometer at the ICP-MS 

Laboratory of the Instituto de Geociências - USP, an iCap-Q model of the Thermo-

Analytical manufacturer. The procedure begins with about 40 mg of powdered rock 

sample, dissolved in Parr bombs in an electric oven, with the addition of nitric acid 

and HF, heated to about 200
o
C for around 5 days, cooled and then heated on an 



 

110 

 

electric plate for vapor-separation of Si as SiF4. Details of the method are described 

in Navarro et al (2008). 

 

5.3. Zircon chemistry 

 

The methodology used for chemical determinations in zircon is briefly 

mentioned here.  

 

Separation of zircon from the host rocks. In a summarized way, the steps 

to be taken are the following: A) selection of clean samples of the host rock (ca. 0.5 

to 3 kg of acidic rocks, up to 20 kg when the samples are basic rocks), which then 

are crushed to appropriate sizes in a jaw grinder. B) the fraction between 100 and 

250-mesh is separated from the crushed material, using sieves. C) the obtained 

fraction is then positioned onto a vibratory table to separate heavy phases such as 

zircon, baddeleyite, titanite, monazite, apatite, and others; D) Magnetic minerals 

(magnetite, pirrotite, etc.) are removed from the sieved fraction with the use of 

magnets; E) phases with different magnetic susceptibilities are separated with the 

Frantz magnetic separator; F) the fractions with the least susceptibilities are 

concentrated by immersion into heavy liquids (bromoform, d= 2.85 g/cm
3
; methylene 

iodate, d= 3.2 g/cm
3
), mainly to separate zircon, baddeleyite and monazite from other 

phases. Remaining sulfides are washed out by dissolution with HNO3. A 

representative sample of zircon (around 100 grains) is then separated manually, 

using a binocular microscope. The obtained zircon grains are mounted with the aid of 

an adhesive tape, and fixed onto an epoxy mount, which is then ground and polished 

to obtain good zircon surfaces for chemical determinations (either with laser ablation, 

or with electron bombardment in a electron microprobe). Most zircon grains are not 

homogeneous, so that they have to be submitted to study with a 

cathodoluminescence technique (CL), to ascertain internal structures (form and 

extent of a core, if present; types and extent of zonation and its geometry; etc.). In 

the CPGEO laboratories (IGc-USP), cathodoluminescence studies are performed 

with a FEI Quanta 250 SEM-XMAX spectrometer (Oxford Instruments), with a 

magnification interval of 95 to 250 times. More details are discussed in Sato et al. 

(2014).  



 

111 

 

Zircon chemistry: determination of major, minor and trace elements by 

LA-ICPMS. The techniques outlined in Gao et al. (2002) and Yuan et al. (2008) were 

followed for the determination of the zircon chemistry, using at the same time the 

expertise gained in our laboratory (Andrade et al., 2010a, 2010b) during 

determinations of trace elements in several reference minerals and geologic 

reference rock materials, such as powders BHVO-2G, BCR-2GBIR-1G (cf. USGS 

2002), and glasses of komatiites (GOR-128, GOR-132), of basalts (KL-2G, ML-3BG) 

and of the quartz diorite T-1G (prepared by the Max Planck Institut für Chemie, cf. 

Jochum et al. 2005). 

 

 

6. WHOLE-ROCK GEOCHEMISTRY OF SAMPLED GRANITOIDS 

 

The whole-rock geochemical data for the sampled granitoids, as far as 

available, are listed in Table 1 (Table 1; cf. Electronic Supplementary Tables), 

together with normative data obtained from the raw chemical determinations, all of 

them plotted on several widely used chemical diagrams which allow an overview over 

(normative) petrography and chemical classifications and pinpoint indications of 

probable environmental features (Figures 17 to 28), always remembering that these 

samples are representative of the Brasiliano granite genesis and are distributed 

within a rather tightly limited area (i.e., the basement slices that cover the 

southeastern portion of the state of São Paulo). The discussion that follows uses 

obviously a very limited amount of geochemical information about each of the cited 

granite bodies, a situation that has to be taken into account when reaching 

conclusions. Nevertheless, the speculation about general geochemical features 

seems to be valid, and can be used to reach tentative conclusions, which more 

detailed studies have to validate, or not. 

The data set, best observed in the usual Harker diagrams (as a function of 

silica content; Figure 17), displays variations in a manner that is to be expected in 

granites worldwide. The values of our granitoids range from 63% SiO2 to about 75% 

SiO2, while contents of total iron oxide (expressed as Fe2O3), MgO, and CaO, as well 

as MnO, show a broadly negative correlation; alkali abundances plot showing an 

increase with silica content. The other minor elements P2O5 and TiO2 behave in the 



 

112 

 

same way as MnO, thus indicating, as expected, that most P and Ti are held in 

accessory and/or mafic mineral phases, also showing a positive correlation between 

MgO and total iron oxide contents (figure not displayed). The trend in Al2O3 variation 

(Figure 17) is grossly similar in all granitoids, with a slight decrease observed in those 

rocks with larger silica contents; surprisingly, the Terra Nova sample (TN-1) departs 

from these projections, presenting a lower than expected alumina content (<12%), in 

contrast with expectations (more or less constant alumina contents for most true 

granitoids). The Itaqui enclave (ITQ-E) is an entirely different rock, if interpretations 

about genesis are correct (namely, it should represent the basic-intermediate 

counterpart preserved in a “mingling” process with the host granitic liquids).  

 

  

  

  



 

113 

 

  

 

 
Figure 17. Harker variation diagrams for major and minor elements, as a function of SiO2 
content. Data belong to the following granite units: ITA-1 and 2: Itaquera; TAP-01 (Taipas, 
main granite) and TAD-1 (Taipas, dike rock); Pe-04 (Perus tourmaline granite); ITQ-2, 4 
(Itaqui main granite); ITQ-E (microgranular mafic enclave in Itaqui); ITQ-D1 (leucocratic dike 
in Itaqui); MD-24 (satellite stock related to Itaqui); CHA-1 (Ubatuba charnockite); Cant-6 
(Cantareira facies);  MD-42B (satellite stock of Cantareira); SR-07 (main facies of São Roque 
granite); ITU-14X (Itu granite); Tico-1, Tico-2 (Tico-Tico rocks), IA-10 (Ilha Anchieta granite). 

 

Thus, major and minor elements, in these plots, show tendencies indicating 

that similar genetic processes are at work in all these examples, certainly no proof 

about possible cogenetic origin; minor discrepancies in genesis (e.g., more or less 

fractionation, or more or less assimilation), are not registered in these Harker 

diagrams. 

More accentuated contrasts, as far as genetic processes is concerned, may 

be found in Harker plots of trace elements (Figure 18). The elements Zr and Hf show 

a certain negative correlation with silica increase (mainly indicating, possibly, a 

decrease in the crystallization of zircons with “differentiation”), while no correlation 

can be observed in the other plotted elemental diagrams. This can be explained by 

pointing out that most of the listed elements (with the important exception of Ba, Sr 

and Eu) are fixed in mafic and/or accessory phases, which do not present a modally 

simple behavior with evolution in these granitoids.  

 



 

114

Figure 18. Harker variations diagrams for some trace elements, as a function of SiO2 content. 



 

115 

 

The commonly used TAS diagram (Figure 19, a version taken from Cox et al, 

1979) indicates that most of the studied rocks are actually sensu-latu granitoids 

(more accurately, granodiorites to true granites (“monzogranites”), with the exception 

of the mafic Itaqui enclave (sample ITQ-E), representing the basic extreme in a 

“mingled” rock system. 

Figure 20 shows the classic modal Streckeisen diagram for plutonic rock 

classification, where the components were here calculated from the normative 

mineralogy (thus, normative Ab + normative An represent the approximate modal 

plagioclase). Certainly an approximation, it nevertheless points out the predominance 

of common “granitoids” among our samples, projected rather closely within a field 

that represents the position of the supersaturated thermal valley, as determined by 

experimental work (e.g., Tuttle & Bowen, 1958). Again, the Itaqui enclave stands out, 

indicating an origin brought about by mingling procedures, far removed from the 

“normal” evolution of granitoid magmas. 

 

 

 

Figure 19. TAS (total alkali-silica) diagram of chemical classification of plutonic rocks (based 
on Cox et al. 1979; Wilson 1989). The curved heavy line separates the alkaline from the 
subalkaline rocks. For legends, see also Figure 17. 

 

 



 

116 

 

Figure 20. Normative classification of granitoids in the QAP diagram (after Streckeisen 
1974). Plagioclase (P) is the sum of normative Ab and An. For legends, see also Figure 17. 

 

The distribution of alkalis in plutonic rocks is a matter that deserves to 

discussed (Figure 21), given the possibility that more extreme compositions are 

representative rocks of rather special genetic links. Our samples carry proportionally 

(a little) more K2O than Na2O, which suggests that the São Paulo basement was 

underlain by protoliths which were enriched (in Proterozoic times?) in K

Na2O (for instance, orthogneisses or mafic granulites, instead of gneisses of 

sedimentary origin?). The diagram also suggests that biotite, not amphibole, should 

be the predominant mafic phase in the sampled granitoids (as well as in most 

Brasiliano granitoids, as broadly confirmed by petrographic descriptions).

Figure 22, by its very nature, can indicate those rocks which carry enough 

alkalis to override the presence of CaO, an oxid

crystallization of amphiboles and eventually clinopyroxenes, as well as calcic 

plagioclase. CaO also diminishes with increasing silica content, so that alkali content 

clearly controls the crystallization of feldspars (enriched in

silica) and the presence of biotite. It is interesting to note that the two

120 

 

The discriminating diagram presented in Figure 25 shows that the majority of 

the granites here analyzed plot in the post-collision field (Pearce, 1996). These 

granites are the most difficult to classify because they were derived from a large 

range of protoliths. In general, it is supposed that they originate, ultimately, from 

enriched mantle sources (through complex subduction and/or intraplate processes), 

and therefore associated to widespread crustal interactions. 

 

 

Figure 25. Tectonic environmental diagram Rb versus (Y + Nb), for the studied granitoids 
(after Pearce et al. 1984), including field for post-collision granitoids (Pearce 1996). For 
legends, see also Figure 17.  

 

According to Whalen et al (1987) and Eby (1990), the type-A granites define a 

distinct group within the granite family, supposed to have crystallized from high 

temperature melts, parameters which are not normally achieved in the crust. Hence, 

the involvement of mafic magmas, or high mantle heat flow, seems to be a necessary 

condition for their formation. Generally, they are characterized by higher Fe/Mg and 

Ga/Al ratios, the result of extensive feldspar fractionation, and abundance in 

incompatible trace elements, stabilized in magmas by Cl and F. Diagrams which can 

classify the granites into several of the currently accepted genetic types, such as “S”, 

“I”, or “A”, are constructed using several trace elements indicators (Whalen et al. 

1987; Eby, 1990), some of which are used here to separate fractionated from 

unfractionated I and S-type granites and these from the A-type. These diagrams use 



 

121 

 

the following data: FeO/MgO versus 10000Ga/Al (Figure 26a), FeO/MgO versus 

Zr+Nb+Ce+Y (Figure 26b), (K2O+Na2O)/CaO versus Zr+Nb+Ce+Y (Figure 26c) and 

10000Ga/Al versus Zr+Nb+Ce+Y (Figure 26d). Our samples plot in different fields, 

such that samples from Tico-Tico, Perus and Ilha Anchieta can be classified as type 

A, while the others correspond mostly to the I or S lineages, or more fractionated I-S 

types. Indices in Figure 26c and Figure 26d show, on the other hand, that the 

samples from Ilha Anchieta, Ubatuba charnockites, Itu, Itaqui (principal granite; 

enclave), Itaqui satellite, and São Roque plot within the A-type field. Tico-Tico and 

Perus would be considered I-S “felsic fractionated” types. A cursory observation of 

these results indicates that geochemical indices would classify these granites as very 

different genetic types. Obviously, these chemical indices, although widely cited in 

the literature, may not capture entirely the complexities inherent in granite 

petrogenesis.

Figure 28 depicts plots of variograms for the studied granites, indicating that 

most of them show marked negative anomalies for W, Nb, Ta, and Ti. Elements Cs, 

Rb, Ba, Sr, Pb (LILE) are however somewhat enriched (main Taipas rock, Itaqui 

samples, Cantareira probes). These values, together with a relative enrichment in 

alkalis (usually over > 6.5%) characterize rocks having a shoshonitic ancestry, 

formed in a geotectonic arc environment, as suggested by some authors (Gill 1981; 

Baluyeva et al. 1988). Shoshonites in volcanic arcs usually appear at a considerable 

distance from the subduction trench, coupled with melting at a significant depth, 

commonly controlled by arc (or retro-arc) rifting. The subduction component in these 

shoshonitic magmas is indicated by the presence of negative anomalies of Nb, Ti 

and Ta in the variograms (Turner et al. 1996; cf. Figure 28). 

 

  

  

 
Figure 28. Variograms (spidergrams) for the studied granitoids; values normalized against 
primitive mantle (Sun & McDonough 1989). For legends, see also Figure 17.  

 

Weathering and erosion processes remove from continental blocks most 

easily the elements that may be carried away by water (such as Sr, Ca, Ba, Mg and 

alkalis), leaving behind the ones that can be incorporated into residual clay minerals 

(either structurally or by absorption, such as Rb and the immobile trivalent REE). 

Therefore, one way of discriminating between the action of igneous and sedimentary 



 

124 

 

processes would be to compare some trace element ratios such as the ones using 

Eu and Sr, both attracted by plagioclase but showing different behaviour in igneous 

and sedimentary environments. During fractional crystallization, or partial melting, 

both Eu and Sr are fractionated into plagioclases, presenting decreasing ratios in the 

liquids that eventually coexist with feldspar-holding rocks. Europium contents also 

decrease in comparison with other trivalent REE, since the reduced Eu
2+

 ion will 

enter preferentially the plagioclase structure, therefore explaining the origin of the 

progressively enhanced negative Eu anomaly in REE normalized diagrams of many 

igneous rocks, a situation that can be equally revealed by the diminishing Eu/Sm 

ratio (Kemp & Hawkesworth, 2003).  

In sedimentary processes, Sr set free from the plagioclase structure is carried 

away by water (e.g., in diagenetic interstitial solutions and during lithification), while 

bivalent Eu, in these environments, oxidizes into insoluble Eu
3+

 and will therefore be 

retained in sediments. Weathering will thus not diminish the amounts of Eu in 

comparison with Sm, so that the ratio Eu/Sm will show a divergent behavior 

depending on the controlling processes (igneous or sedimentary).  

On the other hand, Rb is generally retained in clay minerals during weathering. 

While it behaves as an incompatible element in igneous processes, concentrating in 

the liquid, strontium is captured within the feldspar structure (a compatible 

behaviour), so that the Rb/Sr ratio can become a valuable indicator about the 

controlling process. Kemp & Hawkesworth (2003) proposed to use the ratios Rb/Sr, 

Eu/Sm and Eu/Sr as a means to depict the importance of igneous or sedimentary 

processes in the generation of protoliths (whether purely of igneous or of 

sedimentary origin, or a mixture of both) from which the granitoids magmas were 

derived.  

The ratios Rb/Sr versus Eu/Sr, and Eu/Sm versus Eu/Sr of whole-rock 

analysis for our studied granitoids are depicted in Figure 29 (a and b), suggesting 

that samples Cant-6 (Cantareira) and MD-42B (Cantareira “satellite”), as well as ITQ-

2, ITQ-4, MD-24 and ITQ-E (Itaqui main granite, “satellite” and enclave), and SR-07 

(São Roque) represent non-fractionated granitoids, in comparison with the Bulk Crust 

(BC) composition. On the contrary, samples Tico-2 (Tico-Tico), ITA-2 (Itaquera), ITU-

14X (Itu), TN-1 (Terra Nova) and ITQ-D1 (Itaqui dike) are more differentiated than the 

BC ratios, showing decrease in the Eu abundances relative to the Sm contents, as 



 

125 

 

Eu
2+

 content is reduced by uptake within the plagioclase structure. The marked 

increase in the Eu/Sr ratio suggests that Eu
2+

 capture is more effective than the 

partitioning of Sr into plagioclases.  

Sample ITQ-D1 (Itaqui dike) is the most fractionated within the plotted 

samples, but under more reduced conditions than the main Itaqui granite (samples 

ITQ-2 and -4), given that oxidation increases the abundance of Eu
3+

.  The Perus 

sample (Pe-04) was possibly generated by fractionation from magmas similar to the 

ones that crystallized to form the Itaqui, Taipas and Cantareira occurrences; it was 

however more oxidized than the Itaqui dike magma (sample ITQ-D1). This very 

fractionated magma may have been subjected to additional processes such as 

mixing with other fluids thus generating a chemical fingerprint pointing to interference 

with sedimentary processes in the respective protoliths and/or late control of 

additional fluids, thus explaining the drift of the plots of the cited samples (including 

the most extreme case, Perus) to fields with lower Eu/Sm and higher Eu/Sr; the 

explanation being that Eu was retained in clays and ultimately in feldspars (during the 

passage of sedimentary rocks into recrystallized ones), while Sr was drained away 

during the early history of the corresponding protoliths by sedimentary processes. 

Sample TAD-1 (Taipas dike) plots in a different area, with lower Eu/Sr and higher 

Eu/Sm and Rb/Sr ratios, presenting a positive Eu anomaly, suggesting an evolution 

by previous extraction (crystallization) of at least some plagioclase and the possibility 

of forming very fractionated liquids. 

The samples ITQ-E, ITQ-2 e 4, MD-24 (Itaqui main rock and enclave, Itaqui  

“satellite”), TAP-1 (Taipas main rock), SR-06 (São Roque), Cant-6 and MD-42B 

(Cantareira, “satellite”) plot in the Rb/Sr area with ratios (0.1 to 0.3) comparable with 

BC, while samples  ITA-1 and 2 (Itaquera), Itu-14X, Tico-1 and 2 (Tico-Tico) and TN-

1 (Terra Nova) present much higher  Rb/Sr ratios and a more evolved chemical 

profile. This behavior, as indicated before, may be related to control by weathering 

processes for the corresponding protoliths, maintaining Rb abundances in the 

original clay minerals while extracting the more soluble Sr from the weathering 

residue. An extreme case is that of TN-1 (Terra Nova), similar in some indices with 

the mean A-type LFB granite, showing the lowest Sr and Rb values (2.7 and 82 ppm, 

respectively), and very low values of MgO, Fe2O3(total), CaO, as well as Al2O3 and 

TiO2 (Figure 17).  



 

126 

 

The sample ITQ-D1 (Itaqui dike) presents a Rb content (251 ppm) twice as 

large as that of the main Itaqui granite (ITQ-2 and 4; around 104 ppm); Sr 

abundances are, respectively, 58 and 763 ppm; Table 1). This behavior may suggest 

that this dike is somewhat different, genetically, than the sample representing the 

main granite ITQ -2 and -4 (as also the Itaqui enclave ITQ-E; normative proportions 

of K-feldspar and plagioclase in these rocks are very similar). Sr decrease in these 

crystallizing magmas is controlled by uptake in plagioclase, that of Rb by 

fractionation within K-feldspar; probably, Rb/Sr ratios should not change drastically 

during crystallization of both feldspars in the residual magmas. It is to be observed 

that Rb in the Itaqui dike is as high as in Perus (Pe-04), Itaquera (ITA-1 e 2) and 

Tico-Tico (Tico-1 and 2); Sr contents are also similar (Table 1). The charnockite 

sample CHA-1 is very different from the other granitoids samples, similar in 

composition to the BC analysis (Figure 29), with an almost identical Eu/Sm ratio, but 

higher Eu/Sr, possibly on account of a relative decrease in Sr, showing a behavior 

that would suggest a contribution by meta-sedimentary protoliths.

er zone, or zones, possibly indicating an inherited character, a 

residue of a relictic grain already present in the melting protolith; outer zone, or 

zones, as possible additions during magmatic growth; etc.). The determination of

7.1. Cathodo-luminescence and transmitted-light observations on grains in 

mounted samples 

 

Figure 30 (Figure 30; cf. Electronic Supplementary Figures) presents 

photographs of mounted zircons as observed mostly under cathodoluminescence for 

the studied zircons, in the following order : samples from Cantareira (Cant-6), Itaqui 

(ITQ-2, “satellite” intrusion of Cantareira (MD-42B), “satellite” Itaqui intrusion (MD24), 

Taipas (TAP-1), Tico-Tico (Tico-2), São Roque (SR 07), Itu (Itu-14X), Terra Nova 

(TN-1), Ubatuba charnockite (CHA-1), Ilha Anchieta (IA-10), Perus tourmaline 

sample (Pe-04), Itaqui enclave (ITQ-E), Itaquera (ITA-2), Taipas dike (TAD-1). 

Some samples present predominantly elongated prismatic grains, with little 

color or with a faint yellowish-brownish tone (Cantareira Cant-6 and MD-42B; Itaqui 

(ITQ-2; and MD-24); Taipas (TAP-1 and TAD-1); Tico-Tico (Tico-2); São Roque (SR-

07); Ilha Anchieta and Ubatuba charnockite (IA-10, CHA-1). In other samples, less 

elongated and more equant zircons may appear in considerable amounts, together 

with more elongated forms (e.g., Itu-14X; Terra Nova TN-1; Perus Pe-04; Itaquera 

ITA-2; Itaqui enclave ITQ-E; Taipas dique TAD-1). Very white cores of zircons are 

observed in samples Pe-04 (Perus) and Terra Nova (TN-1), thus indicating possibly 

higher contents of U, Y, and HREE (Figure 30). 

Sizes usually vary between 50 and 400 µm, frequently very similar in most 

samples (see Figure 30).  

Many grains present complex oscillatory zoning, possibly characteristic of 

magmatic crystallization, also showing in some cases somewhat darker cores (e.g., 

ITU-14X, SR-07 e ITQ-E) or, more commonly, darker intermediate or outer zones 

(e.g., Cant-6; ITQ-2, TAP-1, TAD-1, Tico-2; Per-04, TN-1).

obtained from zircons separated from the studied samples. The complete array of 

REE were determined, as well as Ba, Sr, Rb, Th, U, Nb, Ta, P, Ti, Zr, Hf, and Y. Data 

are presented in several ways, as usually depicted in the literature. A first array 

shows variograms (Figure 31), indicating the variations (and similarities, in most 



 

129 

 

cases) present in the trace-element geochemistry of zircons in our granites: in these 

diagrams, the following elements are presented, in the cited order: Ba, Rb, Th, Nb, 

Ta, La, Ce, Sr, Nd, P, Sm, Zr, Hf, Ti, Tb, Y, Tm, Yb, normalized against C1-chondrite 

(McDonough & Sun 1995).

Figure 31. Variograms (spidergrams) obtained for the studied zircons, with values normalized 
against C1-chondrite. Represented samples are Itaquera (ITA-02), Terra Nova (TN-1), 
Cantareira (Cant-6, MD-42B), Itaqui and enclave (ITQ-2, MD-24, ITQ-E), Taipas (TAP-01, 
TAD-01), Ilha Anchieta (IA-10), Ubatuba charnockite (CHA-1), Tico-Tico (Tico-2), São Roque 
(SR-07), Itu (ITU-14X), and Perus tourmaline granite (Pe-04). 

 

Zircon is, of course, the primary host mineral containing Zr and Hf, two 

elements which are always correlated in the presented diagrams, as expected. The 

highest amounts of Hf are found in ITA-2 (11000-14000 ppm), Tico-2 (10000-20000 

ppm), TN-1 (8500-21000 ppm) and Pe-04 (20000-38500 ppm), while most samples 

show contents varying from 8000 to 13000 ppm. These higher ratios suggest that the 

host granites are relatively evolved rocks, derived from differentiated magmas, given 

that in most cases granite evolution follows a path of Hf enrichment with 

differentiation (Hoskin & Schaltegger 2003). 

Crustal materials, in general, maintain a Zr/Hf ratio close to 35-40, the ratio 

found in the chondrite (Weyer et al. 2002). Most of the studied samples, however, 

present ratios somewhat above the chondritic value (cf. Table 2, Electronic 

supplementary tables). Granites Cant-6 and MD-42B (Cantareira), CHA-1 

(charnockite), IA-10 (Ilha Anchieta), ITQ-2, ITQ-E, ITQ-D, MD-24 (Itaqui), TAP-1 

(Taipas), SR-07 (São Roque), and ITU-14X (Itu), show ratios between 42 and 50, 

while samples Tico-2 (Tico-Tico) and ITA-2 (Itaquera) present Zr/Hf ratios around 40 

(with high dispersion, values from 23 to 55, and 34 to 46, respectively); samples TN-

1 (Terra Nova) and Pe-04 (Perus) yield values of 33 and 19, below the chondrite 

average.  

Figure 32 presents the REE diagrams, normalized to C1-chondrite (Sun & 

McDonough 1995). Individual results for several grains are plotted, as well as the 

corresponding mean and median values.
