Table 3 presents ratios often used to define REE and trace elements trends in 

magmatic rocks, which will be used to separate these granite samples into possible 

different geochemical groups. 

It is interesting to note that the main features in Figure 31 repeat themselves in 

the diagrams, all of them presenting systematic peaks for (from left to right) Th, Ce, 

Nd, Zr and Hf (the last two elements being geochemically correlated) and, similarly, 

depletions for La, Rb, Sr, P and Ti, thus presenting (Figure 31) more similarities than 

differences. It is difficult to explain the Ce and Nd peaks, except perhaps on account 

of the relative easiness which allows these elements to enter the zircon structure, 

dominated by HFSE such as Zr and Hf. The same reasons probably apply for Th, a 

natural partner for elements in structures holding Zr (e.g., zircon, baddeleyite). 

This behavior is certainly dictated, in the first place, by crystallochemical 

reasons, controlled by the structure of the host mineral. All granitic magmas show 

certain geochemical similarities, as far as enrichment and depletion of elements is 

concerned. Hence, an increase in the abundances of some HFSE in the granitic 

magmas should induce an uptake of these elements by phases such as zircon (e.g., 

Th and U).  

More than indicating the general similarities, it should be useful to observe the 

differences, which will probably reflect the relative enrichment (or depletion) of some 

elements such as the REE and, to a certain extent, the crystallization conditions of 

the magmas, assuming that the final zircon trace-element chemistry is entirely 

governed by magmatic crystallization (as suggested, for instance, by textural means, 

e.g., zoning behavior). Samples such as Terra Nova (TN-1), Itaqui “satellite” (MD-24), 

Taipas (TAP-01, TAD-01), Ilha Anchieta (IA-10), charnockite (CHA-1) and Perus (Pe-

04) show a remarkable lack of dispersion (as compared to behavior in Itaquera, Tico-

Tico, Cantareira “satellite”, Itaqui enclave and Itu, with wider variations; cf. Figure 31). 

The uniform chemistry in these variograms is to a certain extent repeated in the REE 

diagrams (for instance, relative REE constancy in samples from Taipas main rock 

TAP-1, Ilha Anchieta IA-10 and Perus Pe-04, but showing wider variations in others; 

cf. Figure 32). 

During magmatic crystallization, probably the zircon grains showing larger 

chemical variations crystallized, from beginning to end, under somewhat different 

conditions (e.g., variations in fluid fugacities, or heterogeneous diffusion of elements 



 

135 

 

in the magmas, or greater mobility of zircon crystals in the melt, traversing probably 

different magma batches in a somewhat heterogeneous magma chamber; etc.). On 

the other hand, the remarkable uniformity shown by the zircon grains with rather 

constant trace-element chemistry should indicate surprisingly uniform crystallization 

conditions.

Most of the studied grains in the various granitic samples show a marked 

predominance of LREE (normalized figures), always above 10 times chondrite, a 

limiting value expected to be present in igneous zircons (Hoskin & Schaltegger 

2003). MREE abundances,  such as GdN, are remarkably enriched above chondrite 

values in samples IA-10D (Ilha Anchieta) and CHA-1 (charnockite, the last two 

samples with enrichment factors between 50 to 500), SR-07 and ITQ-E (São Roque 

and Itaqui enclave; 50-1000), ITU-14X (Itu batholith), and ITA-2 (Itaquera), the last 

two with enrichment factors for GdN between 100 to 1000. Even larger enrichment is 

observed in samples TN-1 (Terra Nova; enrichment between 1000 to 10000), and 

Tico-2 (Tico-Tico) and Pe-04 (Perus tourmaline sample: enrichment for both by a 

factor of 10000 to 100000). Enrichment by a factor of 10
3
 to 10

4
 (times chondrite) in 

the HREE, especially when YbN is considered, is also remarkable, an expected 

behavior for many zircons crystallized in granites (Hoskin & Ireland 2000; Hoskin & 

Schaltegger 2003; Wang et al. 2012).  

The REE diagrams (Figure 32) show large variations in the (Yb/La)N ratios, 

depicting somewhat different inclinations from LREE to HREE; e.g., with a median 

value of 10531 (from 1321 to 54134; sample charnockite CHA-1), 1966 (from 907 to 

5534; Taipas TAP-1), 1357 (from 23 to 8537; MD-24), 920 (from 182 to 2086; Ilha 

Anchieta IA-10D). A less pronounced drop in values for the (Yb/La)N ratios can be 

observed in samples ITQ-E (Itaqui enclave), TAD-1 (Taipas dike), MD-42B 

(Cantareira “satellite”), Tico-2 (Tico-Tico), and SR-07 (São Roque). Decline in values 

from  LREE to HREE is more pronounced in the charnockite CHA-1 than in the IA-

10D sample (Ilha Anchieta), although the total abundance of REE in both samples 

are practically identical (median value of 775 ppm, from 451 to 1460 ppm for the 

charnockite, to a median of 718 ppm, from 349 to 1032 ppm for Ilha Anchieta). 

In these variation diagrams (Figure 32), remarkable positive Ce peaks are 

observed in samples from Cantareira (Cant-6, MD-42B), Itaqui “satellite” (MD-24), 

Taipas main rock (TAP-1), Itaqui enclave (ITQ-E), charnockite (CHA-1), and others.

The largest Ce/Ce* [Ce*= (LaNxNdN)
1/2

] anomaly values are registered for samples 

CHA-1 (charnockite), TAP-1 (Taipas main rock), MD-24 (Cantareira “satellite”) and 

IA-10D (Ilha Anchieta) (respectively 37, 34, 32, 13). The positive anomaly for this 

element represents crystallization under oxidized conditions (high oxygen fugacity), 

most notably observed in the cited samples, favoring the change from Ce
3+

 to Ce
4+

, 

the last ion substituting for Zr in the zircon structure. Typical values of the Ce/Ce* 

ratios in these anomalies should vary between 1 and 10 for granitic rocks, but may 

reach higher values in zircons from pegmatites and syenites (2 to 300; Belousova et 

al. 2002; Clairbone et al. 2010; Trail et al. 2012).    

The positive Ce peaks, indicating oxidizing crystallization, are clearly present 

as a single anomaly in various samples from Cantareira main rock and “satellite” 

(Cant-6, MD-42B), Itaqui main rock, “satellite”, enclave (ITQ-2, MD-24, ITQ-E), and 

Taipas main rock (TAP-1), thus indicating for most of the zircon grains a 

crystallization under higher oxygen fugacity. These rocks should be separated from 

those crystallizing entirely under more reduced conditions, especially when marked 

by a negative Eu anomaly (hence, formation and withdrawal of Eu
2+

). This situation 

has not been observed in any of the analyzed samples. In this context, it is 

interesting to observe  those samples presenting both the positive Ce anomaly as 

well as the negative one depicted by Eu behavior (samples Itu, ITU-14X; Terra Nova, 

TN-1; Itaquera, ITA-2; Ilha Anchieta, IA-10D; charnockite, CHA-1; Perus, Pe-04; 

Figure 32). An explanation for this could be as following: crystallization may have 

occurred under oxidizing conditions, then changed to one where reduced conditions 

were dominant (or vice-versa). A textural control of the analyzed spots within the 

crystal morphology could tell which condition prevailed in the first place, to be 

replaced later on by the opposite condition. In some samples, the REE diagrams 

show that the oxidized behavior (high oxygen fugacity) controlled part of the zircon 

grain formation showing a positive Ce spike (restricted to some grains), passing to a 

behavior with an entirely or at least partly smooth variation in normalized REE 

abundances (as shown by other grains in the same sample; e.g., samples Cant-6 

from Cantareira, ITA-2 from Itaqui, SR-07 from São Roque, ITU-14X, from the Itu 

batholith; Figure 32).

Figure 33 shows how most of the determinations of total REE, Y, U and Th on 

zircon grains (plotted against Hf) cluster around 500 to 10000 ppm (for total REE and 



 

140 

 

Y), and around 100 to almost 10000 for both Th and U, therefore with no indication of 

correlation for the respective sample population; Hf median values in all cases are 

around 12000 for these clusters. Overall median U and Th abundances are around 

150 to 300 ppm and 100 to 200 ppm, respectively, but presenting varying 

proportions, sometimes showing strongly enriched zircons in U and Th (e.g., medians 

of Pe-04 from Perus record Th= 1089 ppm, U= 9160 ppm; ITA-2 from Itaquera, Th= 

1106, U=1556 ppm; TN-1 from Terra Nova, U=2175 ppm, Th= 3111 ppm; these 

granitoids, as well as sample from the Itaqui enclave ITQ-E are the ones presenting 

the highest U and Th contents in zircons; cf. Table 3). 

On the whole, the variations observed in element abundances in zircons from 

the same granite are very variable, frequently providing difference in abundances 

over an order of magnitude (cf. also discussion in Pettke et al.2005; Li et al. 2012). 

However, some outliers are present (Figure 33), spreading out in a linear fashion, as 

visible especially for zircons from the Perus tourmaline granite (Pe-04), Tico-Tico 

(Tico-02) and Terra Nova (TN-2), indicating that high Hf abundances (>14000-15000 

ppm) favour (even if slightly) the uptake of the cited elements (U, Th).  

The uptake of Hf in the zircon structure seems to be dependent on 

temperature of the magmas, more than its composition (Clairborne et al. 2006; 

Watson et al. 2006; Bolhar et al. 2008). In this sense, it is interesting to compare the 

presence of Hf with the Th/U ratio for zircons from several samples (Figure 34). 

Although most of the diagrams present the data distributed as clusters, with little or 

no visible correlation, some slightly (negative) correlation can be observed between 

these two indices (Figure 34), especially in Cant-6 (Cantareira), IA-10D (Ilha 

Anchieta), ITQ-2 (Itaqui), TAP-1 and TAD-1 (Taipas main granite and dike), and SR-

07 (São Roque). 

HFS elements Nb, Ta, and Ti can substitute Zr in the zircon structure, 

presenting typical values which, according to the literature, should be as indicated: 

Nb ? 62 ppm, Ta ? 3 ppm and Ti ? 75 ppm (Hoskin & Schaltegger 2003). Our data 

show a wider variation, such as listed in Table 4, than the range cited in the literature, 

as especially visible by the behavior of the Perus tourmaline granite, Pe-04, 

admittedly a much differentiated granite; our intervals are also remarkably higher 

than the figures cited in the literature.

Ce and Eu anomalies as indicators of oxygen fugacities in magmas

The Ce and Eu anomalies determined in the REE diagrams in zircons give 

indications about the crystallization conditions of the analyzed zircon grains, as they 

serve to quantify the oxygen fugacities (Petke et al. 2005; Barth & Wooden 2010; 

Clairborne et al. 2010; Li et al. 2012).

The coexistence of the negative Eu and the positive Ce anomalies in the same 

zircon grains (Figure 32), far from representing an inconsistency, is perhaps better 

explained as representing the depletion of Eu, brought about by the fractionation in 

feldspars, host to Eu
2+

crystallizing magma (e.g., Hoskin & Schaltegger 2003). 

Oxidizing conditions can be depicted in Eu/Eu* and Ce/Ce* diagrams (Figure 

36; Orejana et al. 2011; Wang et al. 2013). In a Eu/Eu* versus Ce/Ce* plot, 

determinations in zircons indicate rather modest oxidizing conditions for most 

samples (formulae for Eu* and Ce* are Eu*=(SmNxGdN)

A more or less well-defined linear relationship between Ce/Ce* and Eu/Eu* is 

observed especially in sample ITQ-E (Itaqui enclave), less so in grains from 

charnockite CHA-1. However, most determined results for the ratio Ce/Ce* cluster 

around low values (e.g., less than 30 or even 10; Figure 36a), especially visible in 

samples Tico-2 (Tico-Tico), ITA-2 (Itaquera), IA-10D (Ilha Anchieta), Pe-04 (Perus),

Nova), Cant-6 (Cantareira granite), TAD-1 (Taipas dike rock) and MD-42B 

(Cantareira “satellite”). CHA-1 (charnockite), as well as granitoids TAP-1 (main 

Taipas granite) and MD-24 (Itaqui “satellite”), show a wider scatter of Ce/Ce* values 

(Figure 36a), possibly indicating that this ratio may be more sensitive to control by 

oxidizing conditions than the Eu/Eu* ratio (Trail et al. 2012).

compared with those determined in the whole rock chemistry in samples ITA-2

feature possibly controlled by plagioclase fractionation. The rock samples from

ITQ-E, MD-24), Taipas (TAP-1 and TAD-1) show  no expressive Eu anomalies. In 

sample CHA-1 (charnockite), a well-defined Eu anomaly is observed in zircons 

(Figure 32), but not in the whole-rock pattern, where the lack of an anomaly may be 

controlled by an interplay between positive and negative contributions to that

8.2. Possible sources for LREE enrichment in zircons 

 

LREE (La to Pr), presenting a larger ionic radius than the middle and heavy 

equivalents, are not easily introduced in the zircon structure as substitutions of Hf 

and Zr (Hoskin & Schaltegger 2003; Hanchar & van Westrenen 2007). On this 

account, La and Ce abundances in igneous zircon are of the order of ppm to sub-

ppm; Ce may be found in contents up to 50 ppm. Our data, on the other hand, 

indicate for many zircon grains an enrichment factor for LREE of the order of 100 

times the chondrite  value, or even higher (Figure 37), for samples Cant 6  

(Cantareira), ITQ-2  (Itaqui), TN-1 (Terra Nova), Pe-04 (Perus), ITU-14X (Itu 

batholith) and ITA-2 (Itaquera); the other samples show lower enrichment factors, 

less than 10
2
. The ratio (Sm/La)N, indicating the slope of the LREE, expected for 

crustal zircons are of the order of 57 to 547, much higher than the ones obtained 

from mantle zircons (11.3-38) (Hoskin & Schaltegger 2003).  

The observation of high abundances of LREE in zircons, a topic discussed 

widely in the literature (Xia et al. 2010; Nardi et al. 2012; Orejana et al. 2012), will be 

addressed in the following lines. A possible explanation is of course that these values 

are fabricated by faulty analysis, in the sense that micro-inclusions of mineral phases 

hosting REE (apatites, monazites, etc.) were also included in the analytical 

procedure, a hypothesis that can be tested using chemical arguments, for instance 

by plotting (Sm/La)N against P (Figure 38a), a plot that, however, shows no 

correlation and therefore is an argument for excluding an explanation based on 

undetected apatite inclusions (see also our discussion on the plot of P versus Ca 

abundances in zircons, above). Monazite inclusions, another source for higher LREE 



 

148

observed in the proper diagram (Figure 38b). LREE e

apatite inclusions in zircon could be recognized in plots of (Sm/La)

8.4. Ti geothermometry in zircons 

 

Ti uptake in zircons is mainly controlled by environmental temperatures and Ti 

activity, aTiO2 (Watson & Harrison 2005), making the concentration of the element a 

valuable tool for geothermometric studies (Watson & Harrison 2005; Watson et al. 

2006; Ferry & Watson 2007). Calibration of this geothermometer (Tzir)  was 

performed with the use of synthetic zircon for higher temperatures (1025 to 1450
o
C) 

and natural zircons for lower temperature conditions (560 to 1170
o
C; Watson et al. 

2006). Diffusion of Ti
4+

 in zircons is a slow process, controlled by substitution of the 

element in the Si tetrahedron (Cherniak & Watson 2007; Ferry & Watson 2007). The 

substitution is most sensitive at pressures above 10 Kbar, making a correction of not 

more than 50
o
C necessary for crystallization conditions for crustal materials, formed 

at around 750
o
C (Ferry & Watson 2007). 

The Ti geothermometer can best be applied to systems with pure TiO2 and 

SiO2 phases (that is, rutile and quartz), but can also be used in igneous rocks 

presenting ilmenite (Cates & Mojzsis 2009). It has been extensively applied in more 

recent studies (e.g., Clairborne et al. 2006; Fu et al. 2008; Orejana et al. 2011, 2012; 

Wang et al. 2013). 

In our work, the geothermometer was applied according to calibrations 

performed by Watson & Harrison (2005) and Watson et al. (2006), under the 

assumption that crystallization proceeds, in the presence of quartz and rutile, at 

around 10 kbar; uncertainties in the obtained temperature estimates of zircon 

crystallization should not be over 60-70
o
C for environmental temperatures around 

750
o
C (Ferry & Watson 2007).

analyzed zircon values. Zircon saturation temperatures in magmas (Tsat Zr) are 

indicated, calculated according to Watson & Harrison (1983), as well as apatite 

saturation temperatures (Tsat Apt), calculated according to Harrison & Watson (1984). 

Chemical data for these calculations were taken from Table 1 (geochemistry of 

rocks).

8.5. Hydrothermal and late magmatic zircons 

 

Most zircons in igneous rocks crystallized from magmas (mainly, those 

presenting a more evolved chemistry), but there are many situations in which these 

zircons are recrystallized varieties, or even formed entirely under non-magmatic 

conditions as, for instance, in those environments subjected to the activities of 

aqueous fluids at high temperature (e.g., Hoskin 2005; Cavosie et al. 2006; Fu et al. 

2009; Bouvier et al. 2012; Lisowiec et al. 2013). Several paths for the generation of 

hydrothermal zircons have been proposed (Hoskin 2005): 

1. Direct crystallization from aqueous fluids; 

2. Ionic exchange between hydrothermal fluids and metamictic zircon of 

igneous origin; 

3. Dissolution of earlier zircons and recrystallization, generating new 

zircons.  

There is no consensus in the literature about the differences in composition 

between the truly igneous zircons and those formed under hydrothermal conditions, 

although several characteristics were pointed out for the second type, namely, an 

increase in contents of LREE, variations in abundances of HREE, and the 

possibilities of preservation or even formation of positive Ce/Ce* anomalies (Hoskin & 

Schaltegger 2003; Hoskin 2005; Pettke et al. 2005; Schaltegger 2007; Fu et al. 

2009).  

The diagram LaN versus PrN has been used by Hoskin & Schaltegger (2003) 

and Cavosie et al. (2006) to show clearly the different fields for hydrothermal and 

igneous zircons (Figure 44). In an extensive study by Yang et al. (2014), it was 

pointed out that zircons formed in the Chinese Baerzhe alkaline granite in the Central 

Asian Orogenic Belt, hosting one of the largest REE, Zr and Nb deposits, show a 



 

rather porous structure, presenting frequently micro

U, Th, Nb and Ta. These zircons were transformed by hydrothermal alteratio

forming phases characterized by an increase in ions easily transported in these 

solutions, such as U, Hf, Nb, Ta, Ti and LREE, the last ions 

accommodated better in the structure under recrystallization than in the one offered 

by igneous zircons (e.g., Hachar & Westrenen 2007; Bakkar & Elburg 2006; Hay & 

Dempster 2009; van Lichtergelde et al. 2009). 

The ion Zr itself is a rather mobile element in evolved peralkaline and 

peraluminous granitic systems, and also in hydrothermal en

and silica (Rubin et al. 1993; Ayers et al. 2012). The solubility of Zr increases by 

formation of ionic complexes with silica and hydroxyl groups. At the same time, 

solubilities of several other elements are also increased, such as

Th, U and Be, especially in hydrothermal fluids with relative abundances of fluorides 

and alkalies (Rubin et al. 1993).

9. SUMMARY AND GENERAL CONCLUSIONS 

 

Several different granites from various geologic domains identified in the 

basement areas of São Paulo state (domains São Roque, Embu, Jundiaí and 

Costeiro, according to Janasi & Ulbrich, 1992), all belonging to the so-called 

Brasiliano granite petrogenetic event, were sampled in order to perform a 

comparative study including litho-geochemistry, coupled with the information derived 

from trace-element geochemistry in zircons, to establish a framework to identify 

general petrogenetic crystallization conditions in those granites. The studied samples 

come from the following granite occurrences: Cantareira, Itaqui, São Roque and Itu 

calc-alkaline batholiths with some “satellite” bodies, Tico-Tico garnet-two mica 

granite, Perus tourmaline stocks, Taipas calc-alkaline bodies, Terra Nova 

occurrence, Itaquera two-mica granite, biotite granite from Ilha Anchieta (an island 

occurrence) and Ubatuba charnockite. Cantareira, Itaqui, Taipas, Perus, Tico-Tico 

and São Roque are positioned within the São Roque Domain, Itu and Terra Nova 

within the Itu Domain, Itaquera in the Embu area, and Ilha Anchieta and Ubatuba 

charnockite in the Costeiro (Coastal) Domain. 

 

1. Whole-rock geochemistry of the analyzed granite samples indicates that 

they belong to meta-aluminous to peraluminous lineages with rather conspicuous K 

contents. The Cantareira (Cant-6) sample and a “satellite” body (MD-42B), as well as 

Taipas (TAP-1), Itaqui (ITQ-2 e 4), the Itaqui enclave (ITQ-E) and an Itaquí “satellite” 

(sampled at the Fazenda Itahyê. MD-24) and São Roque (SR-7) are meta-aluminous 

rocks, with high Sr abundances and a high Sr/Y ratio, presenting smooth normalized 

REE diagrams (no Eu anomaly is present): the parental magmas probably were 



 

166 

 

generated at higher depths and higher pressures (? 15 Kb), under conditions in which 

garnet is a stable phase in the protoliths, while plagioclase should be unstable. The 

other  rocks show a geochemical profile compatible with rocks (or magmas) formed 

at lower crustal pressures, presenting a negative Eu/Eu* anomaly (produced by 

plagioclase interference, capturing bivalent Eu), and lower Sr contents, as well as a 

low Sr/Y ratio; included in this group are Itaquera samples (ITA-1, -2), some Itaqui 

rocks (ITQ-D1, a dike within the main granite), Tico-Tico (Tico-1 and -2), Terra Nova 

(TN-1), Itu batholith (ITU-14X), and Perus (Pe-04). The Itu sample within this group is 

the only meta-aluminous rock. The Taipas dike sample TAD-1 (occupying a 

dilatational fracture within the main Taipas granite) presents a positive Eu anomaly, 

low Sr contents and a higher Sr/Y ratio, features that characterize a residual liquid 

with complete feldspar crystallization as well as mineral phases that incorporate Y in 

their structure (e.g., garnets, monazite). The Ubatuba charnockite CHA-1 presents no 

Eu anomaly, indicating no influence of the plagioclase in the Eu distribution due to 

high quantities of clinopyroxene and hornblende in the rock. The charnockite shows 

features that point to a “primitive” (i.e., not evolved) character: for instance, the 

Eu/Sm ratio is similar to Bulk Crust (BC), a characteristic shared with Cantareira, 

Itaqui (including its enclave), São Roque and Taipas, showing however rather higher 

Rb and Eu contents and diminished Sr abundances than the four cited granite 

occurrences, possibly pointing to a higher contribution of sedimentary processes in 

the genesis of its protolith. Samples ITQ-E, ITQ-2 and -4, TAP-1, MD-24 (Itaqui 

“satellite”), SR-06, Cant-6 and MD-42B (Cantareira “satellite”) present Rb/Sr ratios 

comparable to the BC ratio (between 0.1 to 0.3), while in samples ITA-1 and -2, ITU-

14X, Tico-1 and -2 and TN-1 the ratio increases a hundred times. This heavy 

increase in the ratio can be explained as the result of weathering processes that 

concentrate elements such as Rb in the weathering residue (especially in clays) and 

leached Sr at the same time, features that are, later on, transmitted into the 

recrystallized rocks that probably formed the protoliths of the corresponding magmas 

of the cited granitoids. An extreme example may be TN-1 (Terra Nova), showing 

values of 82 ppm Rb and 2.7 ppm Sr, indicating possibly that the protoliths of 

sedimentary origin concentrated Rb but lost heavily Sr during weathering processes.  

 



 

167 

 

2. The zircons extracted from these samples present, usually, rather high 

contents of REE, Th and U. The normalized variograms (spidergrams) of trace 

element contents in zircon from the analyzed samples present characteristic negative 

anomalies for Rb, Sr, P and Ti. On the other hand, normalized REE patterns show 

almost always a positive Ce anomaly and, for some samples, a negative one for Eu.  

The low Th/U ratios observed in some zircons are controlled by co-crystallization with 

monazite (samples Pe-04, ITA-2 and Tico-02), while dissolution of monazite in 

magmas liberates Th for uptake in zircons, therefore increasing their Th/U ratio in 

some samples (e.g., ITU-14X, TN-1) (cf. Orejana et al., 2011). Negative Rb and Sr 

anomalies in the spidergrams are to be expected in zircons, given possible 

incompatibilities for the incorporation of these elements in the zircon structure, as 

well as their uptake in the crystallizing feldspars. 

 

3. Negative Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu*<1) are observed in samples Tico-2, 

Itu-14X (Itu main rock), TN-1 (Terra Nova), IA-10D (Ilha Anchieta), ITA-2 (Itaqui main 

rock),  CHA-1 (charnockite) and Pe-04 (Perus tourmaline granite) and are determined 

by crystallization of zircon in equilibrium with plagioclase, which favors an uptake of 

Eu
2+

 in the feldspar structure. On the contrary, a positive Ce anomaly (Ce/Ce* >1) 

points to an increase in oxygen fugacities or, alternatively, a “wetter oxidized melt” 

(El-Bialy & Ali, 2013); the feature is best observed in samples CHA-1 (charnockite), 

TAP-1 and TAD-1 (Taipas main rock and dike), Itaqui “satellite” MD-24, Ilha Anchieta 

IA-10D, and Itaqui enclave ITQ-E. 

 

4. A plot of the U/Yb ratio versus Hf, or U/Yb versus Y, clearly shows that 

our analyzed zircons crystallized in continental environments, as opposed to those 

generated during formation of an oceanic crust. 

 

5. The observed high contents of REE (+ Y) in the analyzed zircons can 

be explained by uptake of the elements in those phases, given the possibility of 

coupled reactions occurring during zircon crystallization, with P
5+

 replacing Si
4+

, and 

REE replacing Zr
4+

, with the possible contribution of other elements, such as Al
3+

, 

Fe
3+

, Mg
2+

, Fe
2+

 in interstitial sites, for charge balance. These coupled reactions 

would take the following expression: (Y, REE) + P = Zr + Si (in a 1:1 REE:P 



 

168 

 

proportion, and similar reactions for 2:1, 3:1 and 4:1 proportions; see text, above). 

The other possibility, that of undetected micro-inclusions of phosphates analyzed 

within zircons, was discarded, since no correlation was observed between (Sm/La)N 

versus P, or (Sm/La)N versus Th (and other similar plots). This correlation would 

emerge if apatite and/or monazite were present as inclusions.  

 

6. The calculation of the Ti-in-zircon model geothermometer Tzir (Watson & 

Harrison, 2005) in general yields estimated crystallization temperatures that are 

comparable to the ones obtained for the zircon and apatite saturation temperatures in 

magmas (respectively TsatZir and TsatApt), especially in the case of zircons showing a 

typical igneous texture, with well-formed cores and surrounding oscillatory 

idiomorphic rims. Zircon grains showing cores with an irregular outline, or signs of 

resorption (i.e., of a relictic nature), especially the ones with a dark reflection (under 

cathodoluminiscence) yield crystallization temperatures above 1000
o
C, higher than to 

be expected for magmatic granitic rocks. Correlation plots of Ti versus REE and P 

contents within zircons showed a good positive correlation (coefficients over 0.80, for 

Ti versus REE, and 0.70, for Ti versus P). These features can be explained as a 

result of incorporation of these elements in the zircon structure, by means of Zr 

substitution by Ti and REE, with correlated charge balance by introduction of P in the 

Si site (and, eventually, other elements such as Fe, Al, Mg in interstitial positions); Ti 

may also enter the structure occupying some interstitial positions, in addition to the Zr 

site.  

 

7. Plots of Nb, Ta and Mo against REE + Y, as well as those of P + Ti + Ta 

+ Nb against REE + Y, based on the studies of Hoskin et al. (2005) and Erdman et 

al. (2013), show a clear correlation, suggesting recrystallization of zircons under the 

influence of fluid activities (hydrothermal conditions, as opposed to typical igneous 

crystallization from magmas) . These correlations point to the importance of transport 

of these elements in fluids and the possibility of incorporating them into zircons, a 

situation that may also apply to explain the introduction of U and Th by a similar 

transport mechanism. It is known that these fluids, transporting HFSE, are also 

enriched in halides (chlorides and fluorides), as well as alkalis, silica and CO2, thus 



 

169 

 

providing for a favorable chemical environment which may also help in the capture 

and transport of HFSE (Dubrail et al. 2011; Lisowiec et al. 2013). 

 

8. It is difficult, and certainly speculative, to indicate a possible source 

from which the HFSE, later introduced into zircons, were taken and mobilized, but 

literature discussions can point towards certain possibilities, the mantle being 

foremost among them. Mantle-generated fluids are supposed to be enriched in CO2, 

H2O, halides and HFSE (Bea et al, 2001; Slaby et al, 2012). Our “altered” zircons 

present high abundances of Nb, Ta and Y, as well as of Rb, Ba, Sr (LILE), pointing to 

contributions derived from mantle activities (Martin, 2006), to which contributions 

inherited from crustal sources (the REE) are also added. The general geological 

framework shown by the Ribeira Belt rocks, with their protracted history of 

deformation and recrystallization, magma generation and shear-zone fault activities, 

should also indicate the possibility of parallel extensive fluid activities (the “hidden” 

part of geologic history). There is no way to deny the importance of fluid activities 

during diagenetic processes shaping the final texture and mineralogy of sedimentary 

rocks: fluids would certainly also plays a major role in the long-lasting formation 

history of basement rocks. In a way, the recognition of “altered” zircons, clearly 

showing that the trace-element geochemistry contained in typical igneous zircons 

can be changed rather drastically, is a further indication that fluids play a major role 

overprinting existing zircons. Avenues for fluid transport are certainly present, both as 

metamorphic structures (foliations, etc.) as well as major faults, such as the ever-

present shear-fracture zones in the studied basement areas.

Abstract 
The laser ablation technique, coupled with the use of quadrupole ICPMS equipment, proved a po-
werful tool for determination of trace elements in minerals. At the University of São Paulo, the 
technique was implemented for the study of minerals such as olivines, pyroxenes and biotites. The 
main problem to be tackled is the availability of proper multi-element reference materials usually 
prepared synthetically as glasses with various compositions by NIST and fused rock glasses by the 
Max Planck Institute (MPI) and USGS (basalts, andesite, quartz diorite, komatiites). The best tested 
ones are the NIST glasses, with good homogeneity and reliable compositional data for over 40 
elements. Results are here presented that test additional RM’s. NIST 612 and 610 were used for 
calibration purposes. The best results were obtained for rock glasses USGS basalts BHVO-2G, BIR- 
1G and BCR-2G (better homogeneity and recommended values). Our contribution tests especially 
the MPI komatiites glasses GOR-128 and GOR-132G, basalts KL-2G and ML-3BG, andesite StHs-6/ 
80G and quartz diorite T-1G, discussing homogeneity issues and providing new data. There is a 
need for additional preparation of reliable reference materials. 

 
Keywords 
Laser Ablation, Mass Spectrometry, Geological Reference Materials, Fused Rock Glasses

1. Introduction 
Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, hyphenated with laser ablation (LA-ICPMS), represents an im-
portant tool for the direct chemical analyses in solid phases. The main advantage is the possibility of determin-
ing the composition even in substances with a complex matrix, as usually present in geologic and environmental 
materials, semi-conductors, and others. The technique has the advantage of high sensitivity, a wide range of li-
near intensity responses, and requiring little surface preparation, without presenting major problems with conta-
mination issues. The obtained results can be expressed as either elemental or isotopic proportions and the spatial 
resolution is of the order of 10 to 300 µm and depth resolution is about 60 nm per pulse [1].  

Mass spectrometers can isolate ions with a positive charge effectively by their mass/charge relations. Three 
types of equipments are available, each one with its own advantages and shortcomings, the quadrupole setting, 
the time-of-flight performance and the high-resolution sector arrangement. 

The quadrupole mass spectrometer setting is the most cost-effective, and hence has become the preferred in-
strument in many laboratories. The equipment generates voltage intervals and radiofrequencies that can stabilize 
a definite ion within the quadrupole rods and guide it towards the detector window. Given a predefined setting, 
ions with a different mass-to-charge ratio will become unstable and be eliminated within the vacuum system. All 
the desired spectra of ionic masses can be quickly scanned within the quadrupole. Although this analyzer works 
in a sequential fashion, it can separate efficiently more than 5000 atomic mass units (amu) per second [2].  

Therefore, Q-ICPMS equipments associated with laser ablation can perform very fast multi-element determi-
nations of over 40 elements, with sensitivities of the order of ng?g?1 in any mineral phase, or of materials hidden 
within them, such as fluid inclusions, in a time-span that does not exceed 1 or 2 minutes of operation. 

These techniques opened up new fields of research in igneous petrology, mineralogy and geochronology, de-
termining the distribution of trace elements in several phases (both solid as well as liquid), and enabling also the 
calculation of the corresponding partition coefficients between mineral pairs, or mineral phases and melts [3] 
[4]. 

The main drawback of the quadrupole setting associated with LA is the possibility of isotopic fractionation 
during analysis, a subject widely discussed in the literature [5] [6], as well as the lack of adequate Certified Ref-
erence Materials (CRM) for most of the analyzed minerals, a deficiency that may be corrected with the prepara-
tion of new homogeneous synthetic materials [7]. Many such multi-elementary synthetic or natural materials are 
already available, such as the well-certified NIST 610 and 612 glasses and the synthetic materials prepared by 
melting of rock powders [8] [9]. The NIST RM’s are synthetic glasses with around 40 elements, present in 
amounts close to 30 mg?kg?1 in the 612 sample, and up to 500 mg?kg?1 in the 610 material. They were used in 
this contribution as calibration materials. The USGS substances, widely considered the best RM’s, are the basal-
tic glasses BHVO-2G, BIR-1G and BCR-2G, already subjected to many determinations. The Max Planck Insti-
tute prepared several additional glassy RM’s, such as the komatiites GOR-128 and GOR-132G, the basalts 
KL-2G and ML-3BG, the andesite StHs-6/80G and the quartz diorite T-1G, still to be tested, as far as certified 
values and homogeneity is concerned. 

The implementation of this methodology at our laboratory started with the handling and analytical determina-
tions using NIST materials for calibration, followed by analytical determinations of the USGS synthetic basaltic 
glasses (BHVO-2G, BIR-1G and BCR-2G) [8], and, additionally, of the substances offered by the Max Planck 
Institute [10]. The results obtained for these reference materials during the last 4 years of analytical determina-
tions in our laboratory (where these materials were also analyzed as unknown substances) are here presented and 
discussed. 

2. Analytical Methodology 
The indications given in [11] were used as a basis for the implementation of the analytical methodology for trace 
element determinations in minerals in thin section and in reference materials with the LA-Q-ICPMS methodol-
ogy.  

Mean analytical time spent for analyzing up to 44 elements was 120 s (60 s for reading a blank, 60 s for pre-
paring the instrument and reading results from the analyzed sample). Intensities in cps are calculated as concen-
trations in real time by the Glitter® software (developed by the GEMOC program, Geochemical Evolution and 
Metallogeny of Continents, Macquarie University, Australia) [12].  

Our results were obtained from the determination of the before-mentioned RM’s (USGS basalt glasses 



S. Andrade et al. 
 

 
703 

BHVO-2G, BIR-1G and BCR-2G; Max Planck’s komatiites GOR-128 and GOR-132G, basalts KL02G and 
ML03BG, quartz diorite T-1G, andesite StHs-6/80G). The obtained results were processed with the Glitter® 
software [12] for drift correction with the use of an internal standard, together with a check on background, 
spectral signs and analytical quality, and finished with the calculation of results in weight units. Instrumental 
parameters are listed in Table 1, and data on the analytical performance are quoted in Table 2 and Table 3. 

The analyzed elements and their masses (cited in Table 3) were determined with a dwell time of 8.3ms and 
integration time of 1660 ms; total time of analysis was 120 s, the first 60 s measuring the background gas fluxes 
(Helium, He and Argon, Ar) reaching the plasma after passing through the sample cell, followed by 60 s devoted 
to data acquisition of the materials removed from the laser spot.  

The sequence for data acquisition is as follows: 
Nist-612 (a), Nist-612 (b), sample (1), ···, sample (6), Nist-612 (c), Nist-612 (d), sample (7), ···, sample (14), 

Nist-612 (e), Nist-612 (f). 
Cleaning was performed after each sample analysis for about 2 minutes with He fluxes, a procedure that sta-

bilizes rapidly the background values, more so than an alternative method, such as obtained with the use of Ar-
gon gas. Readings from Nist-612 (a, b, c, d, e, f) were used as an internal standard and for drift correction during 
the entire 1-hour analytical work. The entire procedure lasts about 3 hours, counting also laser and plasma stabi-
lization times at the beginning of the determinations.  

Isotopic interferences occurring during analysis, such as the ones due to 28Si17O+, 27Al18O+, 90Zr2+ on 45Sc+; 
43Ca16O+ on 59Co+; 44Ca16O+ on 60Ni; 135Ba16O+ on 151Eu, and several others, can however be ignored, since they 
are usually very limited in dry plasmas, with hydroxyl and oxygen absent. The daily rate of generation of oxide 
was controlled holding ThO+ formation lower than 1%. The formation of double-charged species, such as Ba2+, 
was kept to a maximum of 3%, controlling the gas fluxes.

Determination of elemental concentrations can be achieved by means of any of the three cited methods: 
1) Entirely by external calibration with a solid reference material; 
2) External calibration with a solid reference material coupled with internal standardization; 
3) Calibration using solutions. 
In our laboratory, the second type of calibration was implemented. The external reference material was used 

simultaneously with an internal standard. This procedure represents a more robust calibration method, since a 
correction can be applied on the ablation yield of the sample (the mass of removed material) and the external 
reference material. The methodology is especially adapted for use with the Glitter® software [13]. In addition, 
matrix effects and signal drift can also be corrected. In practical terms, the internal standard is represented by a 
major constituent found in known concentrations both in the sample and the reference material. Calcium, in par-
ticular, has proven to be an excellent internal standard for many minerals and the NIST glasses. The three minor 
isotopes of the element (42, 43, 44) can be used better for calibration purposes, since their ablation behavior is 
similar to the one shown by petrogenetically important minor elements (e.g., REE). For correction purposes, it is 
assumed that the signal drift occurs linearly with time and at a similar rate for all isotopic masses. When Ca is 
present in concentrations below 1%, other elements can be used as internal standard, such as Mg our even Si. 

The concentration of elements, even though calculated directly with the Glitter® software [12], can also be 
obtained by defining the intensity integration points for background and the sample analyzed by laser, using the

3. Obtained Results 
Data obtained during the last 4 years in our laboratory for USGS basaltic glasses BCR-2G, BIR-1G and BHVO- 
2G are listed in Tables 5-7. These RM’s were used as quality control standards with 30 to 60 obtained values for 
each analyzed element. Reference values for LA-ICPMS are quoted in [11] and in [10]. In the GEOREM site 
[14] preferred values are also listed with a mention of the used analytical technique. 

Data obtained for the Max Planck Institute basaltic glasses KL-2G and ML-3BG, andesite StHs-6/80G, quartz 
diorite T-1G and komatiites GOR-128 and GOR-132G are quoted in Tables 8-13 (six to twelve determinations 
for each material).  

Data obtained for materials BHVO-2G, BCR-2G and BIR-1G were calibrated against the synthetic glasses 
Nist-610 or 612, while the RM from the Max Planck Institute were calibrated exclusively against Nist-612. 

4. Discussion of Results

Figure 2. Variation diagrams obtained for the REE contents in the BHVO-2G, BCR-2G and BIR-1G 
basaltic glasses, normalized with C1 chondrite [16] [17].                                       

 
Figures 3-5 show the variations in obtained and preferred mean values for the Max Planck RM’s (basaltic 

glasses KL-2G and ML-3BG, andesite StHs6/80G and quartz diorite T-1G, komatiites GOR-128 and GOR- 
132G). In these diagrams the observed errors are calculated for our obtained results compared with the preferred 
values for these materials cited in [17].  

Variations diagrams for REE are presented in Figures 6-8 normalized with respect to the C1 chondrite [16] 
[17].  

Figure 3 shows that most of the obtained values are placed between 85% and 115% of the expected mean 
values; the exception is Mo in KL-2G. The values obtained for the REE in basalts ML-3BG and KL-2G (Figure 
6) are very close to the expected ones. 

Some obtained values shown in Figure 4 are higher than the recommended figures cited for the medium to 
heavy REE and for Y, Zr, Mo and Ti in the quartz diorite T-1G, but lower than the recommended figures for Cr, 
Pb, Ni and Zn. These results may be caused by some tiny inhomogeneity of the reference material, locally con-
centrating heavy REE and HFSE and diluting the concentration of elements like Cr, Pb, Ni, Zn and Sn, as shown 
by [18] for the RM ATHO-1G.  

The obtained values compared with the expected ones for the andesite glass StHs6/80G are somewhat outside 
the limit of ±15% for the following elements: Li, Cr, Co, Ni, Cu, Ga, Rb, Mo and Cs. Chromium and Ni defi-
ciencies are also observed in T-1G, possibly indicating calibration problems, other than inhomogeneous distribu-
tion. The REE variation diagram, presented in Figure 7, shows that the obtained values for andesite StHs6/80G 
is very close to the expected values, while the medium to heavy REE in T-1G shows increased values. 

In komatiite GOR-128 (Figure 5), the main elements showing diminished values in relation to the expected 
ones are Li, V, Cr, Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Rb, Mo, Cs, Pb, U. In sample GOR-132G (Figure 5) the same relation-
ship is observed for elements Ni, Cu, Zn, Rb, Mo, Cs, Ce, Th and U. These elements show values that are very 
much increased or diminished when compared with NIST-612, which may not be the best calibration material to 
be used for this exercise. On the other hand, lack of homogeneity (see [19] and [20]) may be another explanation, 
possibly caused by quench crystallization of olivine, which could sequester some elements. A larger set of ana-
lytical data, not restricted to our limited number of determinations, is needed. The REE variation diagrams pre-
sented in Figure 8 (komatiites) show that the obtained values are close to the certified values. 

5. Conclusions 
The obtained values for the several reference materials made available by the USGS and the Max Planck Insti-
tute cover a rather wide spectrum of elemental abundances for the over 40 elements determined with the LA-Q- 
ICPMS technique, the methodology used in this contribution.

Figure 4. Average values obtained in relation to preferred values for several elements in glasses T-1G 
(quartz diorite) and StHs6/80G (andesite), compared with the mean certified values cited in [17], cf. 
Table 10 and Table 11.                                                                   

 
The used technique provides high quality results, in terms of analytical accuracy, and is also very fast. The 

samples can be prepared as thin sections, with a thickness of around 40 to 60 microns, or as mineral grains 
mounted within polished epoxy resins. 

Interferences can be kept at minimum levels, a result achieved with the use of dry plasma, thereby diminish-
ing the influence of agents such as present in aqueous acid systems (O2?, OH?, Cl?, 3NO

? , etc.). However, iso-
topes such as 135Ba, 139La, 140Ce, and others may interfere on medium and heavy REE, even if the level of oxides 
is kept below the recommended value of 1%. Increased values of some REE may be caused by the generation of 
several spurious REE molecular species (e.g. [21]). The point is illustrated in Figure 6, where 155Gd may owe its 
increase to interference by 139La16O+. Careful selection of isotope species is therefore recommended, before re-
lying on one or the other isotopes for analytical calibrations.

Figure 5. Average values obtained in relation to preferred values for several elements in komatiite 
glasses GOR-128 and GOR-132G, compared with the mean certified values cited in [17], cf. Table 12 
and Table 13.                                                                          

 

 
Figure 6. Variation diagrams obtained for the REE contents in basaltic glasses KL-2G and ML-3BG, 
from the Max Planck Institute, normalized with the C1 chondrite [16] [17].                         

 
The rock glasses prepared by the Max Planck Institute cover an adequate spectrum of elements important for 

studies in igneous petrology, but the materials seem to present a lack of homogeneity for some elements, de-
pending on the analyzed mass and of the spot used for identification [15] and may therefore be the cause for the 
observed discrepancies in obtained results. More tests are certainly needed to test statistically this hypothesis, in 
order to certify these glasses as proper equivalents of the USGS materials. 

The use of internal standards, especially MgO and CaO, is a necessary tool to standardize obtained results 
with our discussed technique. But many minerals may lack sufficient contents of CaO to be subjected to the LA- 
Q-ICPMS methodology, a fact that limits the scope of the glasses prepared by NIST, with low to very low MgO 
contents [22] [23]. Another factor to be considered is the possibility of fractionation of many elements, depend-
ing on the used internal standard [24]. There is certainly a need to continue the search for an adequate prepara-
tion of proper rock standards to be used for LA studies in minerals.

Timing and sources of granite magmatism in the Ribeira Belt, SE Brazil: insights 

from zircon in situ U-Pb dating and Hf isotope geochemistry in granites from the 

São Roque Domain 

Valdecir de Assis Janasi
1
, Sandra Andrade

1
, Antonio Carlos B.C. Vasconcellos

2
, Renato 

Henrique-Pinto
3
, Horstpeter H.G.J. Ulbrich

1 

1
Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São Paulo, Brazil; 

2
autonomous geologist; 

3
Department of 

Sciences Appliquées, Université du Québec à Chicoutimi (UQAC), Canada 

Abstract 
 

Eight new in situ U-Pb zircon age determinations by Shrimp and LA-MC-ICPMS reveal 

that the main granite magmatism in the São Roque Domain, which is largely dominated 

by high-K calc-alkaline monzogranites with subordinate peraluminous leucogranites, 

occurred between 604±3 and 591±4 Ma. Importantly, this small temporal range is ca. 

20-30 Ma younger than previously admitted based on U-Pb TIMS dates from literature, 

some of which obtained in the same occurrences now dated. The observed discrepancy 

seems related to the presence of small Paleoproterozoic inherited cores in part of the 

zircon populations used for TIMS dating, which could also respond for the unusually 

high (up to 10 Ma) uncertainty associated with most of these ages. The younger age 

range now identified for the São Roque granite magmatism has important implications 

for the evolution of the Ribeira Fold Belt. Whilst previously admitted ages ca. 620-630 

Ma substantiated correlations with the widespread and intensely foliated high-K calc-

alkaline granitoid rocks of the neighbor Socorro-Guaxupé Thrust Nappe (potentially 

associated with an accretionary continental margin), the ~ 600-590 Ma interval seems 

more consistent with a late deformation tectonic setting. 

Strongly negative eHf(t) characterize the magmatic zircons from the São Roque Domain 

granites. An eastward increase from -22 in the São Roque Granite to -11 in the 

Cantareira Granite and neighboring stocks suggests an across-domain shift in granite 

sources. Such eastward younging of sources, also indicated by Sm-Nd isotope data from 

granites and supracrustal sequences in neighboring domains, is suggestive that some of 

the first-order limits and discontinuities in this belt are not defined by the strike-slip 

fault systems traditionally taken to separate distinct domains. Although the 

negative eHf(t) and eNd(t) indicate sources with long crustal residence for all studied 

granite plutons, the observed range is more radiogenic than the values calculated at 600 

Ma for both the Mesoproterozoic (1.5-1.8 Ga) passive-margin metavolcano-sedimentary 

sequences of the São Roque Domain and their inferred Archean to Paleoproterozoic

1. Introduction 

 

The use of in situ techniques (Shrimp and LA-ICPMS) for U-Pb zircon dating 

offers, besides the obvious advantages of simplified preparation procedures and speed 

of analysis,  the opportunity of avoiding crystal domains with evidence of inheritance or 

late disturbance as an important bonus. Even though the achieved precision of both 

techniques (typically 1% relative, or ± 5 Ma at ~600 Ma) does not permit to resolve 

temporally events identified by field criteria in many individual plutonic bodies, in 

some cases they may be advantageous over the more precise TIMS technique. In 

particular, they allow obtain a large number of concordant ages in texturally-controlled 

portions of the crystals that are fundamental to unambiguously identify true magmatic 

crystallization ages. This is particularly true when determining the crystallization ages 

of granitic rocks from some parts of the Ribeira Belt in SE Brazil, where previous TIMS 

U-Pb zircon dating has revealed the frequent presence of inheritance (e.g., Janasi et al., 

2001; Prazeres Filho et al., 2003). In fact, the influence of inheritance may be too 

difficult to avoid when multi-grain fractions or even single grains are used, which may 

in practice result in imprecise and sometimes unreliable ages. 

The São Roque Domain is a fault-bounded segment of the Ribeira Belt that 

corresponds to the northern extension of the Apiaí Terrane, mostly composed of ~1.8-

1.4 Ga meta-volcanosedimentary sequences of rift and passive-margin character, which 

were metamorphosed and intruded by large volumes of granite in the late 

Neoproterozoic (Ediacaran). In this study, we selected seven among the most 

representative granite plutons from the São Roque Domain to perform U-Pb zircon 

dating by Shrimp and LA-ICPMS; some of them were previously dated by TIMS, but 

the results remained unpublished and carry relatively high (8-12 Ma) uncertainties 

(Topfner, 1996; Ragatky, 1998). 

We also determined Hf isotope ratios in the same portions of crystals sampled 

for U-Pb dating, thus pioneering the use of this isotope system for granites in this 

domain. The Hf isotope system revealed a particularly useful tool for inferences on the 

petrogenesis and tectonic significance of the São Roque granites, especially when 

integrated with previous geological and geochemical studies, including whole-rock Sm-

2. Geological setting 

 

2.1. The São Roque Domain in the tectonic framework of SE Brazil 

 

The Ribeira Belt corresponds to the central segment of an extensive 

Neoproterozoic orogenic system running roughly parallel to the present Atlantic 

coastline from latitude 16
o
S in Brazil to 35

o
S in Uruguay. The northern ~N-S oriented 

segment of this system from latitude 16
o
 to 21

o
 S is the Araçuaí Belt (Fig. 1) where, 

after a series of Mesoproterozoic rifting episodes, a passive margin developed at the 

eastern margin of a continental mass stabilized at ~2.05 Ga (the São Francisco craton). 

After ca. 800 Ma, this evolved to an active margin with the closure of an ocean that lied 

between the São Francisco and Congo cratons (Alkmim et al., 2006).  

The continuity of a stable cratonic area west of the Ribeira and (south of latitude 

27
o
S) Dom Feliciano belts is less obvious, mostly due to cover by the extensive 

Phanerozoic Paraná Sedimentary Basin (Fig. 1). Geophysical evidence has been used to 

infer the presence of cratonic blocks beneath the Paraná Basin (the hidden 

Paranapanema “craton” of Mantovani & Brito Neves, 2005, and the northern 

continuation of the Rio de la Plata craton; Rapela et al., 2007). In many current tectonic 

models, these “cratonic blocks” would have amalgamated to each other and to the São 

Francisco Craton in earlier episodes of Neoproterozoic evolution, before accretion of 

the eastern terrains of the Ribeira and Dom Feliciano belts.  

The metavolcano-sedimentary sequences comprising the Ribeira Belt correspond 

to passive margin deposits developed mostly from 1.8 to 1.4 Ga in the Apiaí Terrane 

(Siga Jr. et al., 2011, Juliani et al., 2000), and possibly later in the eastern Embu 

Terrane. Expressive magmatic arc terranes are recognized east of both the Ribeira Belt 

(the Rio Negro arc; Tupinambá et al., 2012) and the Dom Feliciano Belt (the 

Florianópolis-Pelotas batholith and African counterparts, Basei et al., 2005). Magmatic 

arc activity and related plate convergence are inferred to have started as early as 800 

Ma, and no discontinuity with arc systems associated with the Araçuaí Belt is described. 

Moreover, evidence of expressive granite generation beginning at ca. 780 Ma is

widespread in the easternmost portion of the Ribeira Belt (Embu Terrane; Vlach, 2001; 

Cordani et al. 2002).  

 

The São Roque Domain (SRD) is one of several fault-bounded blocks that make 

up the south Ribeira Belt, and represents the northeastern portion of the Apiaí Terrane 

(Fig. 1; Campos Neto 2000; Heilbron et al., 2008). Our recent work on sedimentary 

provenance in metasandstones from the SRD (Henrique-Pinto et al., 2014) indicates 

source areas that are very similar to the São Francisco craton, leading to the suggestion 

that the Apiaí Terrane corresponds to the SW extension of the eastearn passive margin 

of the São Francisco Paleoplate, an interpretation that is consistent with gravity data 

(Rocha 2009). 

The SRD hosts meta-volcano-sedimentary sequences of dominantly 

Mesoproterozoic ages (e.g., Hackspacher et al., 2000; Juliani et al., 2000; Henrique-

Pinto and Janasi, 2010) and is, like all other domains of the Ribeira Belt, intruded by 

significant volumes of Neoproterozoic granites. The SRD is bordered to the north by the 

Socorro-Guaxupé Nappe (SGN), an allochtonous high-grade terrane that exposes a large 

(~20 km) vertical section of the Neoproterozoic crust also intruded by large volumes of 

granites and whose origin is alternatively linked in the literature to the Brasilia or to the 

Ribeira Belt. 

 

2.2. Neoproterozoic granite magmatism in the São Roque Domain 

 

Neoproterozoic granite magmatism is widespread and voluminous in the Ribeira 

Belt and has been subject of several reviews in recent years (e.g., Janasi & Ulbrich, 

1991; Heilbron et al., 2004). Most of the granites were generated in a<100 Ma time 

interval (650-560 Ma), but significantly older and younger manifestations are reported 

(e.g., ~750-800 Ma occurrences of orthogneiss from several domains, and the ~500 Ma 

“G5” granites found only in the Costeiro Domain), expanding the whole history of 

Neoproterozoic granitic magmatism to a range of as much as 300 Ma. It is well known, 

on the other hand, that the age range of peak magmatism may be shorter within 

individual domains, and shows a regional shift, with a general tendency to be younger 

toward SE; this pattern is followed by the ages of the post-orogenic magmatism, 

indicating progressive stabilization of the fold belt in this direction.

Granites from the SRD occur as a series of plutons whose shapes are often 

strongly controlled by NE-directed transcurrent faults (Fig. 2), indicating that their 

emplacement overlapped the development of the Ribeira Belt strike-slip tectonics. By 

far the most typical granite type forming the largest plutons is a porphyritic biotite 

monzogranite to granodiorite/quartz monzonite with K-feldspar megacrysts (2-4 cm in 

length) set in a medium to coarse-grained matrix. The metaluminous character of these 

granites is indicated by the presence of abundant accessory titanite; hornblende is 

present in the more mafic samples, but may be rare in some occurrences. Chemically, 

they are usually SiO2-poor, often straddling the limit between acid and intermediate 

rocks (64-68% SiO2); relatively high mg# (35-45) and high K/Na are typical, thus 

classifying as high-K calc-alkaline (HKCA) granites (Fig. 4). Other typical geochemical 

signatures are fractionated REE patterns lacking significant negative Eu anomalies, high 

contents of LILE (Ba= 1000-2000 ppm; Sr= 600-1000 ppm), and high Sr/Y (often >30). 

A contribution from contemporaneous mafic magmatism is evident in some 

occurrences, in the form of scattered mafic synplutonic dykes and mafic microgranular 

enclaves. Often more evident are evidences of contamination by assimilation of 

metasedimentary rocks, which may appear as xenoliths or strongly modified mica-rich 

enclaves. 

  Two elongated plutons with subalkaline affinities occur at the westernmost 

portion of the SRD, both showing locally the rapakivi texture, and considered in some 

works as of post-orogenic character. The São Francisco Granite fits better into the 

definition of A-type granites, as it is dominated by fractionated, high-SiO2 granites, with 

low Sr (<100 ppm) and weakly fractionated REE patterns ((La/Yb)N= 12-15 with 

strongly negative Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu*= 0.2-0.3) (Wernick et al., 1993; Godoy et al., 

2010). The Sorocaba Granite, with characteristic elongated shape, is constituted of 

usually non-deformed more mafic porphyritic monzogranites; although chemically 

distinct from the HKCA granites (e.g., <300 ppm Sr, moderately fractionated 

((La/Yb)N= 15-20) REE patterns with negative Eu anomalies (Eu/Eu*= 0.4-0.6)) is of 

more ambiguous affinity.  

Other minor occurrences of subalkaline granite are known from the central 

portion of the SRD, as late occurrences within the Cantareira Granite (the Canivete type 

of Dantas, 1990) and the deformed Vila dos Remédios Quartz Syenite. 

The Tico-Tico Granite is a small E-W elongated (7 x 1.5 km; area= 10 km
2
) 

occurrence, but constitutes the largest pluton entirely composed of frankly peraluminous

largest HKCA plutons (especially in the São Roque Granite, Fig. 3a) or as isolated 

bodies, among which the peculiar garnet-tourmaline aplite-pegmatite Perus Granite is 

the most outstanding. 

A large number of medium-sized granite plutons of diverse composition occur at 

the easternmost portion of the SRD (Igaratá region). These were grouped by Campos 

Neto et al. (1983) in several suites, on the basis of variations in modal composition 

(monzogranite to granodiorite/quartz monzonite, with small diorite bodies), mineralogy 

(usually metaluminous to marginally peraluminous) and texture (porphyritic to 

equigranular; foliated to massive). Geochemical and Sr-Nd isotope data for these 

granites were presented by Ragatky (1998), and revealed predominance of high-K calc-

alkaline granites that, although in some cases are similar to the main plutons from the 

central SRD, are commonly less Ba and Sr-rich and show more radiogenic Nd isotope 

signatures (see below). 

 

 

3. Methods 

 

In situ isotope determinations in zircon by LA-MC-ICPMS and Shrimp aiming 

to obtain space-resolved ages and Hf isotope ratios were the main tools used in this 

work.  The zircon crystals were extracted from 6-8 kg granite samples using standard 

techniques of milling, magnetic and dense liquids concentration. Previously to the 

microanalyses, cathodo-luminescence imagens were obtained from the epoxy mounts 

with 50-100 crystals, and carefully studied to identify textural features of the zircon 

crystals. Whole-rock major and trace-element data (by XRF and solution-ICPMS, 

respectively) and Sr-Nd isotope data were obtained for samples chosen for our study, as 

part of their characterization, and to allow comparison with literature data. All analyses 

were performed in laboratories of the Instituto de Geociências, Universidade de São 

Paulo, Brazil. Details of the analytical protocols of all methods employed are presented 

in Supplementary File 1.

A large dataset of whole-rock geochemical analyses is available in the literature 

for the main granite occurrences of the SRD, mostly from unpublished academic theses 

and papers published in the local literature in the 1990’s (e.g., Dantas, 1990; Andrade et 

al., 1994; Morteani et al., 2008; Wernick et al., 1993). These data were generated in 

different laboratories, what in some cases may respond for slight systematic differences; 

these however do not hinder the general comparisons made here. Since the purpose of 

this work is not explore the geochemical evolution of these occurrences, we just 

illustrate some key features of the SRD granites in variation diagrams presented in 

Figure 4; these diagrams are useful to set the samples studied here into the geochemical 

variation identified in the different plutons, what will be explored in the next session. 

Further considerations about the implications of some key geochemical aspects of the 

SRD granites are discussed in item 6.2.1. 

Whole-rock Sr isotope determinations are available in literature for a few 

granites from the SRD (Tassinari, 1988; Ragatky, 1998). There is a wide variation in

Only a few granites from the São Roque Domain were subject of previous 

systematic Sm-Nd determinations, which is particularly true of the plutons from the 

central portion of the domain studied here. However, a collection of Sm-Nd data exists 

for plutons occurring at the westernmost (Sorocaba and São Francisco granites) and 

easternmost (several small plutons in the Igaratá region) portions of the SRD (Dantas et 

al., 2000 and Ragatky, 1998). 

The results for six new Nd isotope determinations are presented in Table 1. 

eNd600 are negative and within the range previously known for the SRD (-15 to -9), with 

an eastward increase in eNd600 and correspondent decrease in Nd TDM (e.g., Nd TDM= 

2.15 Ga in the São Roque Granite and 1.65 in Cantareira MD-42b). 

eNd600 for all granite occurrences, including data from literature, are indicated in 

Figs. 2 and 3.  

 

 

5. Zircon age and Hf isotope determinations 

 

5.1. São Roque Granite 

 

The westernmost studied pluton is the ~160 km
2
 São Roque Granite, which has, 

in plant, the rough shape of a triangle, with the base partly defined by the N70E-directed 

Taxaquara Fault (Fig. 2). 

The pluton was mapped in detail by Andrade et al. (1994) who recognized a 

main unit of porphyritic hornblende-biotite monzogranite to granodiorite distributed 

throughout the pluton (Fig. 3a). This unit is intruded by small occurrences of pink to 

gray inequigranular biotite monzogranite whose distribution suggests a discontinuous 

body of roughly half-ring shape at the pluton’s central/southeastern portion and by pink 

medium-grained equigranular monzogranite with associated coarse-grained tourmaline-

muscovite granite at the pluton’s northern portion (Fig. 3a).

Sample SR-07 corresponds to the predominant porphyritic hornblende-biotite 

monzogranite typical of the São Roque Granite, and was collected in a roadcut in the 

Livio Tagliassachi Road (SP-053/280) close to the access to the Castelo Branco 

Highway (UTM coordinates of all samples used in this study are listed in Tables 2-4; 

full results of whole-rock geochemical analyses are in Supplementary File 2). A 

chemical analysis shows that the granite is relatively primitive with 64% SiO2, 1.7% 

MgO, 3.2% CaO, with high K2O (4.8%) and high K2O/Na2O (1.6) typical of a 

metaluminous high-K calc-alkaline granitic rock. A moderately fractionated chondrite-

normalized REE pattern ((La/Yb)N= 29) with a weak negative Eu anomaly (Eu*/Eu= 

0.8) (Fig. 5) and high Sr/Y (40) are typical.  

Sample SR-05 is an inequigranular biotite granite collected in a roadcut 7 km to 

the south of SR-07 along the same road. This granite has a much more evolved 

composition with 75% SiO2, 0.2% MgO and 1.2% CaO, and shows a less fractionated 

REE pattern *(La/Yb)N= 12) with lower LREE contents and well-defined negative Eu 

anomaly (Eu*/Eu= 0.57); Sr/Y is lower (19). These features suggest that, if related to 

the predominant São Roque granites, the magma that generated SR-05 resulted from 

fractionation involving plagioclase and a LREE-bearing accessory mineral. 

 

Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating 

Zircon crystals from SR-07 are short (100-200 mm), with ~2:1 aspect ratio and 

well developed oscillatory zoning. U contents are 600-1000 ppm (average 791 ppm), Th 

350-900 ppm (average 609 ppm), and Th/U varies from 0.6 to 1.0 (average 0.76). An 

exception is core 23.1, with extremely high Th (9000 ppm) U (4000 ppm), Th/U 2.5, 

black in CL. Inherited core 18.1 (see below) has extremely low Th/U 0.02 due to Th ~3 

ppm. 

LA-ICPMS determinations were performed in 26 spots, and most are nearly 

concordant (Table 2). With the exclusion of two inherited cores and two points with 

larger errors, a concordia age is obtained from all remaining spots, and yields 602.6±3.8 

Ma (2s; MSWD= 0.05, probability of concordance= 0.83; Fig. 7) as the best estimate of 

the age of this granite.

5.2. Itaqui Granite and Fazenda Itahyê Stock 

 

The Itaqui Granite is a 120 km
2
 pluton elongated in the E-W direction, 

extending over 24 km parallel to Taxaquara Fault, which defines its southern contact. 

Wernick & Ferreira (1993), based on detailed mapping, recognized that the bulk of the 

pluton was built in two main phases of intrusion.  

The early phase consists of two units of hornblende-bearing porphyritic granitic 

rocks with 2.5-3 cm K-feldspar megacrysts. The less voluminous and more 

differentiated monzogranite unit (with CI~6; 68-69% SiO2; 0.8-0.9% MgO) occurs as a 

<2 km-wide border wrapping the more primitive granodiorite unit (with CI~15; 64-65% 

SiO2, 1.8-2.2% MgO) along the western half of the pluton where it attains its greater 

width (up to 8 km) (Fig. 3b).  

The late phase comprises two ellipsoidal stocks that intrude the previous units at 

the southern portion of the pluton, and thus make up its southern contact over most of 

its extension (Fig. 3b). Both are composed of inequigranular biotite monzogranites with 

rare to absent K-feldspar megacrysts. The western stock (~10 x 4 km) is composed of 

more primitive monzogranites (CI~9; 66-69% SiO2; 0.9-1.2% MgO) as compared to the 

eastern stock (~5 x 2 km) (CI7; 69-70% SiO2; 0.5-0.8% MgO). 

Both early and late phase Itaqui granites are characteristically high-K calc-

alkaline (metaluminous, with 3.7-4.4% K2O and K2O/Na2O= 1.3-1.0), with high Sr 

(600-900 ppm) and Ba (1000-1900 ppm). Chondrite-normalized REE patterns are 

typically fractionated with negligible Eu anomalies, typically with  (La/Yb)N= 50-60 in 

the compositionally intermediate Pedreira Cantareira and Aldeia da Serra units and 30-

40 in the more primitive Barueri and Mutinga units (Wernick et al., 1993). Along with 

high Sr/Y (50-60, reaching higher and extreme values in the more fractionated units, 

~80 in Pedreira Cantareira and 160-220 in Mutinga), this is indicative of deep-seated

The Fazenda Itahyê granitic stock is a small (<2 km
2
) granite occurrence 

located ~3,5 km to the NE of Itaqui, and is composed of non-foliated porphyritic 

hornblende-biotite granodiorite in all mineralogical and geochemical aspects similar to 

more primitive unit of the Itaqui Granite early phase (cf. Supplementary File 2). 

 

Sample petrography and geochemistry 

Samples ITQ-2 and ITQ-E from the Itaqui Granite were collected in the Polimix 

quarry located at the central portion of the pluton (Fig. 3b). Apart from its lower K2O 

(2.9%) and Ba (620 ppm), sample ITQ-2 is a typical porphyritic biotite monzogranite 

from the more primitive early phase unit. Sample ITQ-E is a medium- to fine-grained 

basic enclave with 50% SiO2 from the same quarry. Both samples have relatively high 

mg# (0.43-0.46), Sr (~800 ppm), and fractionated REE patterns ((La/Yb)N=31 in ITQ-2 

and 18 in the enclave, which has higher HREE contents) with nearly absent Eu 

anomalies (Eu/Eu*= 0.89 and 0.97, respectively). 

Sample MD-24 from the Fazenda Itahyê granite is a porphyritic hornblende-

biotite monzogranite; its chemical composition both in terms of major and trace-

elements is nearly identical to that of ITQ-2, apart from higher and more typical K2O 

(4.3%) and Ba (1350 ppm) contents. 

 

Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating  

ITQ-2 crystals are 100-300 µm in length, with aspect ratio 2:1 to 4:1. Cores may 

be unzoned or show oscillatory zoning; a few cores have convolute aspect; borders are 

typically oscillatory zoned. Typical Th/U ratios are in the range 0.4-0.6 (average 0.44; 

one exception with 1.1); average U is 537 ppm. 

Sixteen points were analyzed, by Shrimp and show small discordance (Table 3). 

A concordia age of 595.1±4.6 Ma (MSWD= 2.1; Fig. 8) was obtained from 12 points (4 

were discarded because of high 
204

Pb), and is interpreted as the crystallization age of 

this sample.  

ITQ-E crystals are all short, 2:1, but show two populations with equivalent 

abundance: (1) crystals with oscillatory zoning, which may have light limpid cores in 

CL images; (2) nearly homogeneously black crystals in CL images, which may reflect 

high U cores; thin light rims are present in a few of these crystals.

A Concordia age of 598.3±3.5 Ma (MSWD= 0.28, Fig. 7) was obtained from the

Zircon Hf isotope geochemistry 

The Hf isotope composition of zircons from sample ITQ-2 is relatively 

homogeneous, eHf(t) varying from -19.3 to -15.5 (average -17.4 ± 1.4, 1s; spread of 4 

eHf units; Fig. 9).  

Zircons from mafic enclave ITQ-E have a wide variation of eHf(t) (11 eHf 

spread). Crystals from population (2), black in CL images, have markedly least negative 

eHf(t) (-11 and -12), whereas the more negative values (-19.3 to -20.3) are associated 

with light limpid cores in zircons from population (1) (Fig. 9). Values of eHf(t) in 

oscillatory zoned portions are in the same range of zircons from host granite (-17.4 to -

14.5). 

The Hf isotope composition zircons from the Fazenda Itahyê granite MD-24 is 

as homogeneous as those from Itaqui sample ITQ-2 (a 4 eHf units range) and has 

similar eHf(t) (-19 to -14.5; average -16.9 ± 1.4).  

 

5.3. Cantareira Granite and satellites 

 

The Cantareira Granite is the largest granite occurrence in the São Roque 

Domain, attaining batholithic dimensions (~360 km
2
); an indentation of country rock 

along its western-central portion indicates that the batholith shall correspond in reality 

to the junction of two plutons (Fig. 3c).  

The northern pluton has an ellipsoidal shape with its main length (25 km) along 

N45E, being wider in the SW portion (12 km); it delimited to the east by the N40E-

directed Mandaqui Fault (Fig. 3c). The main rock type is a porphyritic biotite 

monzogranite with scarce hornblende similar to the predominant granites in the São 

Roque and Itaqui plutons. Except at its southern border, where it is intruded by the late 

stock of more fractionated porphyritic monzogranite (Canivete facies), the border of the 

northern pluton  is made up of a variety of granite types, including banded, foliated and 

an inequigranular more felsic variety.   

The southern pluton, like the São Roque and Itaqui granites, has its southern 

limit defined by the Taxaquara Fault, along which it extends for ca. 12 km; is has a 

roughly circular shape in plant, being connected to the northern pluton by a bulge that 

has a width of 2-4 km (Fig. 3c). It is mostly constituted of a porphyritic biotite 

monzogranite not different from the predominant facies of the northern pluton. 

The Taipas granitic stock is a small satellite (2 km
2
) located immediately to the 

west of the Cantareira Granite, in the region between the northern and southern plutons 

(Fig. 3c). The main rock type is a porphyritic biotite monzogranite usually more felsic 

than the typical Cantareira granite, but it is compositionally diverse, and a facies similar 

to the typical Cantareira porphyritic biotite monzogranite is locally present.  

The Perus tourmaline granites correspond to a series of small bodies of aplite-

pegmatite that occur in the neighborhood of Taipas and Cantareira northern pluton (Fig. 

3c). These occurrences have attracted the attention of several researchers because of 

their peculiar mineralogy, chemical composition (extremely fractionated; rich in several 

incompatible elements as B, U and Rb) and structure (characteristically banded, with 

alternating aplite and pegmatite bands) (Teupenheyer, 1994; Morteani et al., 2008). 

 

Sample petrography and geochemistry 

Sample CANT-6, collected in the Basalto quarry, located at the westernmost 

portion of the northern Cantareira Granite, is a typical porphyritic biotite monzogranite. 

Sample MD-42b, collected in a roadcut in the Bandeirantes Highway (SP-348), is a 

coarse-grained syenogranite from the southern Cantareira Granite, and is 

petrographically and chemically similar to the Canivete facies described by Dantas 

(1990). 

Sample TAP-1 from the Taipas stock was collected in the Pedreira Construcap, a 

quarry located at the Av. Raimundo Pereira de Magalhães, Perus, close to the Basalto 

quarry. It is a porphyritic biotite monzogranite with 2-3 cm K-feldspar megacrysts set in 

a medium to coarse-grained matrx.

The porphyritic samples from both Cantareira and Taipas are geochemically 

very similar, with ~68% SiO2, high K/Na, high Sr/Y and very fractionated chondrite-

normalized REE patterns without Eu anomalies (Fig. 4, 5). The coarse-grained 

Cantareira syenogranite MD-42b is more evolved (72% SiO2) and has lower Sr, but has 

in common with the other two samples the high Sr/Y and fractionated REE patterns 

without Eu anomaly. 

Pe-04 sample, representative of the Perus granites, was collected in a roadcut at 

SP-21 Highway (Rodoanel Mario Covas). It is a medium-grained equigranular to 

inequigranular tourmaline granite with banding defined by 1-2 cm thick tourmaline-rich 

layers. It has a very evolved composition with 72% SiO2, very low MgO, Ba and Sr and 

high Y (40 ppm) and Rb/Sr (9). Its REE pattern is unfractionated with relatively high 

contents of HREE and a deep negative Eu anomaly. 

 

 

Zircon morphology and U-Pb dating 

CANT-6 zircon crystals are 200-400 µm in length with aspect ratio 2:1 to 6:1. 

Cores show oscillatory zoning; a few cores have convolute aspect; possible inherited 

cores are small either light or dark in CL images; borders are typically oscillatory 

zoned; dark rims are rare and very thin. Typical Th/U ratios are in the range 0.4-0.7 

(average 0.5; three cores are exceptions with 1.6-1.7); average U is 308 ppm. 

Twelve points from CANT-6 zircons were analysed by Shrimp, and most are 

<10% discordant (Table 3). Six points define a coherent age group, and allow obtain a 

concordia age of 598.6±3.9 Ma (Fig. 8). Three points not used in this regression yield 

younger 
206

Pb/
238

U ages (479-571 Ma), which are attributed to high U, high 
204

Pb or 

strong discordance (Table 3). Another three analyses have slightly higher 
206

Pb/
238

U 

ages (606-612 Ma), are virtually concordant, and may correspond to antecrysts inherited 

from early phases of the Cantareira Granite. 

MD-42b zircon crystals are relatively big (up to 500 mm in length) with 3:1 to 

5:1 aspect ratios. They show oscillatory zoning with a general tendency to become 

darker (U-rich) in CL images towards the border. In some cases, a homogeneous, wider 

black border is present; usually, these crystals have CL-bright cores, suggesting that 

they record a long history of magma evolution. Th/U are similar to those of CANT-6 

zircons (0.3-0.7, average 0.54), but U (U 450-800 ppm average 575 ppm) and Th (150-

400 ppm, average 317 ppm) are higher.
